reviewText: I love DM of M&M so much. It is a fantastic action RPG that had a rough release due to glitches and bugs and it never got the love it deserved. I really am saddened a bit that a ton of gamers out there missed out on this game because of all the bad PR over issues that have been fixed through patches. The game still holds up even today. The combat is so satisfying and puts other 1st person RPGs to shame. The use of physics is amazing and really alows you to approach fights how you want, as a fighter, mage, archer or a mix. If you're looking for a hidden gem, then this is the game for you. It'll be bitter sweet when you end up having so much fin with it, and then you realise how you missed out on the multiplayer that the game offered. But at least you got to experience the single player.\n\n5/5

reviewText:
One of the best games I (re)played this year.
In fact, if not for what Valve did to VTMB, I'd be happy to sing GABEN's praises for Valves creation of the source engine.

++Deep and well thought out melee combat system, that rewards players that look to use their surroundings to their           advantage.
++Interesting story that's not the usual save the world because you have to business.

++ Excellent level design that doesn't force you to fight everything in the game if you're the stealthy type (Although with the kick function, I'm not sure if anyone wants to play stealth anyway)

++ High replay value to see the different endings and the different choices available to you in the story as well as the different play styles.
++ Demon for a conscience and guide.


- Short, so very short. (Although I assume 14-15 hours is ok these days...)
- limited RPG leveling system.

Overall this is an excellent game well worth the asking price.

reviewText:
I started this game up expecting something along the lines of Oblivion, seeing as I recall them being released around the same time, but I got something entirely different, but not unwanted. Despite putting you on a linear path, there are just so many different ways you can go about handling yourself along the path, and I personally enjoy that. In addition, there are plenty of awesome secrets that leave me looking around for any kind of secret buttons or breakable walls along the way, and I just love how this game rewards you for it. Upon launching, I noticed this game is run on Source Engine, which had me delightfully surprised. DMMM Utilizes the technology wonderfully and the combat alone would leave me thinking it was a different engine entirely.

Downsides consist of crashes, which are long beyond being worked on due to the game's age. However, if you're able to fix those loading crashes, then I guarantee that a great game waits for you on the other side of those loading screens, however cheesy some of the characters and dialogue are.

Basically, I'm giving this a 10 outta 10, because I haven't had this much fun with a singleplayer RPG since Oblivion and Skyrim. Definitely on par, and plenty of variety to keep you going.

reviewText:
I've heard about this game before. It was probably the first fantasy FPS I've seen.
Got it on a sale and boy was I pleasantly surprised. I've played the whole game through in one sitting.

Despite the story, characters and voice acting being rather generic and the game being very linear, the combat and mechanics of the game are really good.
The game features multiple weapon types such as swords, daggers, bows, axes, staffs and shields. Tools such as hammers and pickaxes can be used as weapons too.
The game has 3 (small) skill trees that all can be leveled independently (though it is recommended to stick to one at the beginning) and unlock new combat moves, spells or increase your basic stats.
Combat is pretty simple but can be approached in different ways. You can throw props at enemies and kick them into hazards. Use a frost spell to freeze the ground and watch them slip off into a pit. Priceless.

Because it runs on the Source engine you can expect decent physics. The game has a lot of destructible objects lying around that you can use to throw at your enemies.
The game even has half life 2's gravity gun (reskined into a telekinesis spell) that you can use to mess around with.

Another thing worth mentioning is that you can grab and climb up ledges, ropes and chains. Later in the game you also get a rope bow that lets you attach ropes to wooden surfaces and climb up them.

I'm not arachnophobic but god damn the spiders in this game. The game seems to have a serious spider fetish. In fact the whole story is linked to spiders.

Speaking about spiders, they are absolutely terrifying. Reason being that the character and npc design in terms of models and textures is great. Stuff looks interesting and quite believable. From dull gray castle guards and bald necromancers to sexy demon ladies. All really well made.

When specing into the stealth build the game suffers from the same problem Skyrim does. You can stand in darkness or crouch in semi dark areas and just backstab enemies one by one as others come to check what happened. It becomes ridiculously easy to kill enemies. Not to mention just shoot your bow from a hidden spot and enemies will not know what hit them. If you get spotted however you'll have a hard time as the game is pretty darn hard. I started on the hard difficulty and had to start over because it was too hard, especially because I didn't spec the right skills at the start.

TL;DR:

Pros:
-Fun, diverse combat
-Good physics
-Kicking things
-Great npc design in terms of models and textures
-Kicking things into other things
-Optional quests that change certain story aspects and the final outcome; multiple endings
-Kicking things off things
-Rope bow
-Kicking things into other things
-Gravity gun
-Replay value
-Source engine; runs great on old pcs while looking relatively good
-Multiple routes in some cases
-Lots of worthwhile secrets.

Cons:
-Generic characters
-Predictable story
-Boring voice actors
-Linear levels
-Little RPG elements; no stores, no open world, no backtracking
-No mod tools (considering it's the source engine); dead multiplayer as a result
-Conveniently placed spiky plates to kick enemies into everywhere

Great game overall. Really underrated. Definitely gets a must play recommendation from me.

reviewText:
Dark Messiah of Might & Magic puts players in a first-person perspective, allowing them to immerse themselves in the legendary Might and Magic universe as never before.

It is also the world's first fantasy action game to feature a complete first-person combat system. It takes full advantage of the Source Engine's exceptional technological enhancements in areas such as character animation, advanced AI, real-world physics and shader-based rendering.

- Ubisoft

I have played this game during my early childhood and I must admit that once I started playing this game I felt stuck to it and completed it over and over again multiple times.
A game that despite being released in 2006, it’s yet fully capable of taking down some modern games within the same genres.

A fine example of what a good adventure and a first-person action game should be, Dark Messiah of Might & Magic is a remarkable example at its finest.

Overall aspects of Dark Messiah of Might & Magic
Adventure combined with the storyline:

The adventure that this game is capable of, is reasonable with the addition of secret places that contributes to a careful exploration of each area players find themselves in. Despite being strictly locked only to its main quest and some other minor side quests, it also contains a short amount of role-playing and key decisions throughout the game.

The storyline isn’t the best, it lacks a strong backbone or a base to begin from, and it is based mostly in surprise elements and new elements that will always shape players way of thinking and seeing things as they progress further in the game.

Graphics and game play mechanics:

The graphics Dark Messiah is capable of projecting with its Source Engine, despite not being the best for its time, are still pretty good and well-balanced with the game play mechanics and user interface.

About the game mechanics, it is focused not only to give players a very pleasant first person melee/ranged combat experience with many different styles and opponents, but also a strong presence of the use of the surrounding game atmosphere and items during all sorts of conflict.

Combat:

Despite the rich game combat moves the game allows players to execute, you might feel that most conflicts you face will be ultimately resolved by the use of front kicks combined with the use of the game surroundings and objects around to terminate your enemies.

This can be easily a 'Pro' for most players since it is quite enjoyable to watch enemies being kicked off to spikes or to be kicked off against fragile wooden crates, but maybe a 'Con' for some.

User interface:

The user interface in this game is simple, clean and again, it does match well with everything else giving players a very good gaming experience.
There is only one way to access your character info, skill points, and quick toolbar which is located at the right top side of your inventory that offers a very simple and easy way to access everything you want.

Music and the voice acting:

Despite this game containing more sounds related to the atmosphere of each part of the game than music itself, both are pretty much reasonable in the end I would say.

The voice acting is decent I believe, but sometimes it just feels that it doesn’t fit whenever there is music being played during a cut scene and voice simultaneously.

Game difficulty:

The game difficulty is very well balanced to meet the tastes of those who wish a enjoyable adventure without struggling that much, to those who want it hardcore with difficult opponents.

Price:

The game price that has also been the same for the last few years is incredibly worth it, with or without sales, the content and adventure this game has to offer is totally worth its base price.

Conclusion
I would rate this game 79 out of 100 or 3.9 out of 5.0 stars. An enjoyable adventure with a fair amount of content and a vast adventure with decent graphics and game play for a very good price.

reviewText:
Dark Messiah of Might and Magic is hands down one of the most entertaining games I have ever played in my life. To be honest, the story is lame, the levels are pretty linear, and after one or two playthroughs you aren't likely to find any new hiding spots for super-secret treasure(though there are quite a few of them).

But this game's combat makes up for all of its flaws, story or otherwise. I have never played a game with more engaging, interesting, or balanced combat than this one. It's the only reason I come back to this game, and as you can see from my logged hours, I have come back to this game time and time again.

The combat is fairly basic to begin with, you can hit things hard or not so hard, you can block with a shield or parry with a one-handed weapon, you can shoot enemies from far away with a bow. However, as you progress into the game and start earning skill points, combat very quickly becomes a deep experience. The game carries three classic releplaying game archetypes: the mage, the rogue, and the warrior. But the part that makes it so wonderful is the complete freedom you have to spend your skill points in any way you please. You can be sneaking up on your opponents wearing heavy armor and slinging fireballs if you want to.

Just play the game, that's really all there is to it. It's well worth the meager investment.

reviewText:
Played this bloddy thing like 3 times, in 3 different styles, and I also got the extended port for Xbox360. After that much time playing this game, I can safely tell you, it's worth it on a sale. Here's why:

Ever wanted a game with a story as good as the first Half Life, that's as linear, but more RPG-Like? Then, this is your game. The only difference, is that the main character speaks, and you have legs as your crowbar.

Made with the source engine, the graphics of the game still look great today. The story, even though not being a f#cking master-piece, it's decent and entertaining, and the gameplay...Well, ♥♥♥♥ing love it.

You can be, whatever you want to be. You want to be like Havel from Dark Souls, a huge armored rock that slays everthing in one hit, but it's slow as progress with Half Life 3? Want to be a camping sniper who can trickshot someone in the balls in slow motion? Want to be the medieval Adan Jensen, and use stealth to the max, executing people from the back? Or just want to be Leonidas, and kick everyone on the balls, and throw them to the pits of hell? I'm not kidding, I did that already, even sended the video to a famous channel long time ago.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WCpNJbKedF8

You also have offensive and defensive magic, and they're also fun to use...But I always end up taking stealth. The game has a few endings, and counting that this is as linear as modern FPS's (but with four times thework on the actual game), it's good!

The game also has multiplayer. Now, I don't know if the multiplayer comes already with the full game, or you buy it stand-alone, but sadly, it's almost dead. You have to understand, the game is really old...But there are still a few servers, most of them russian servers. And if you're able to play without getting banned by hacking" (turns out

reviewText:
A cult classic from the creators of Dishonored, Dark Messiah is an interesting game.  It's listed as an RPG but that's misleading; it's like calling Dishonored an RPG.  Both have skill trees, both have a very small amount of decision making which results in low chaos vs high chaos in Dishonored.  Without spoiling anything, Dark Messiah is similar in that regard.  It's not truly an RPG, there are no dialogue choices or anything like that.  There are simply three major plot decisions.

One particularly interesting aspect in this game is that you don't necessarily play as the good guy.  I'll just leave it at that without spoiling much.

This game is known primarily for its gameplay mechanics, combat in particular.  It's a first person action game that has separate skill trees for melee combat, magic, archery, as well as some miscellaneous skill trees.  Furthermore, there are different types of melee weapons to choose from: twin daggers, swords, and staves.  Each has different properties, pros, cons, and combat animations.

One of the best features of this game's melee combat is that you have different swings/strokes depending on your movement.  Holding W and releasing a power attack for example delivers a different attack than holding A + power strike.  This is something I've demanded for years, and this is one of few games that offers it.

Most spells are offensive and elemental based but there are some exceptions.  The player is expected to go down every weapon skill tree apparently, since archery is too useful in boss fights.

This being a source game, it's almost entirely physics based.  Arkane Studios took advantage of this and emphasized using the environment to kill your opponents.  Knock down a bunch of heavy debris on them, kick them off of a cliff, impale them on spikes, you name it.  Combined with the ability to chain spell effects and other things together (e.g., spill oil on an area and light it on fire with a fire spell or arrow, or shoot a lightning spell into water to electrify it), Dark Messiah seems to provide more ways to kill opponents than any other game, and you can see from my library that I've played a lot.  Even more ways to kill people than Dishonored, which lacks the environmental emphasis.

People often say that The Elder Scrolls games should have this game's combat.  They are absolutely right.  Conceptually, this game has the best combat mechanics of any action game.  However, despite everything I just said, the gameplay/combat is riddled with flaws/oversights, the game lacks an engaging story/plot (RotFodder's pizza analogy is spot on), and it may be a bit too long for its own good.

The combat is fantastic on paper but has flawed execution.  First of all, the game is quite rough around the edges and clipping issues are fairly common which is extremely annoying.  There are some stupid delays when blocking attacks and counter attacking, or using daggers, and other situational things like that.  Also, unlike most first person action games, you actually have to be very precise with your swings.  It seems like the player's hitbox with melee weapons is actually the weapon itself; this makes sense, however it's not good in practice.  This type of thing only works with the Wii controller, it's stupid to have it in a regular game like this.  Reach/range is really wonky in this game.  Goblins seem to have the same reach as humans and orcs.

At the end of the day this game comes across as quite clunky by modern standards, but by 2006 standards it must have been a gift from God (I didn't play it in 2006 but I've played plenty of 2006 games in 2006, Red Steel was the best action game I had played at the time).  Because of it's clunkiness I find it less enjoyable than Dishonored as an action game.  Dishonored's mix of advanced action mechanics and unbelievable, flawless fluidity is only matched by the Shadow Warrior remake.  But then Dark Messiah has so many advantages like the environmental uses, spell/effect combos, and more varied melee attacks than Dishonored.  As usual, we'll never get it all.

Dark Messiah is known to be challenging, but it has that old school unbalanced challenge where if you raise the difficulty, enemies just deal far more damage than you even when using the same attack.  It will take around ten flame arrow spells to kill a regular human opponent for example, but they can kill you in four (and that's with upgraded max health).  If you like unbalanced no holds barred difficulty then perhaps you'll like this, otherwise I recommend sticking to Normal mode which is more balanced.  I favor balanced difficulty with smart AI.  This game's AI is functional enough although hilariously bad at times.

Dishonored is known for its stealth, and that's one area where this game lacks.  It's far more linear than Dishonored, the climbing system is awfully clunky and barely works (clunkier than Thief Gold's even), and you're generally unable to one hit kill enemies from behind even with backstab.  This game is clearly meant to be an action game first, stealth game secondary.  To this day Dishonored remains the only game I've seen that's equally proficient in both.

In terms of atmosphere, this game bears an uncanny resemblence to Thief.  Some sections even tricked me into pressing Thief's key bindings!  The resemblence is so strong at times, particularly in crypts.  This game also has a Rope Bow for shooting rope arrows into wooden surfaces... sound familiar?  Although Thief's rope arrows are less restricted and work more often.

It's no secret that this game relies entirely on its combat.  The plot and all of the dialogue are pure cheese.  It's cliche after cliche.  Character development is mostly non existent.  This is all intentional though, the game is not meant to have an enthralling story or serve as a drama of any sort.  It's just meant to provide a challenging but very fun killing experience.  It mostly does that, although its clunkiness and lack of polish makes it frustrating at times.  Plenty of times this game would get tiresome and repetitive, but then I'd unlock a new ability and all of a sudden it's fun again until I use that ability many times.

TL:DR - This game is all about killing things and it has very good killing mechanics overall, the best on paper as far as action games go but the fact that it's somewhat clunky and very unpolished can make it annoying.  It's meant to be fun and challenging, and it mostly succeeds but with a number of hitches.  It drags on a bit and gets tiresome toward the end.  Decent game but would not play again, at least not entirely.

I did not proofread this review.

reviewText:
Even being as old as it is, Dark Messiah still has, hands down, one of the best combat systems I have ever seen in a video game. Few other medieval fantasy games have the amount of fluidity and control over a character's actions as DM does. Your character takes into account whether you are moving quickly, what direction you have moved your mouse, and how long you have pressed the attack button in determining what attack will be done.

The physics in the game are great as well. Ever wanted to kill a horde of orcs by only throwing crates and barrels at them a la Donkey Kong style? In this game, you can! Ever wanted to mess around for a while watching Necromancers play slip and slide on ice traps you've laid down? In this game, you can! Want to fight dirty and kick an enemy  off a cliff? In this game, you can!

Other games such as Morrowind/Oblivion/Skyrim may have an open world with a more developed lore surrounding it, but they absolutely pale when it comes to their combat systems. Any person who has played Dark Messiah will agree.

On another note, this is still one of the few games in which you can enjoy a full view of your character's body when looking downwards. Games being made today still don't have this option, which is somewhat embarassing since this game had it implemented perfectly since 2006.

Lastly, this is one of the few games that genuinely feels as though you have actually taken down something massive and dangerous. The colossal size of some of the creatures, such as the wyverns and cyclops in this game, are genuinely huge, and require out-of-the-box strategizing to take down. For comparison's sake, I'll use Skyrim. Let's be honest, Skyrim's dragons are somewhat pathetic, if they seem to have trouble even dealing with common folk and can be taken down by common every-day arrows and fire spells. In DM, these creatures are actually quite dangerous, even towards the end of the game, and when you've killed a boss creature, you feel like you've earned it; it's an actual accomplishment that you look back on with pride.

You owe it to yourself to play this game.

reviewText:
I cannot count the amount of playthroughs I have done with this game, but to date one of the best RPG's ever made. The review scores really baffle me. While the story is generic and the voice acting sort of meh the combat and campaign are incredible. Imagine an RPG where skill progression doesnt just give you number increases, but tangible abilities, spells, moves and perks. Every encounter is like a battle arena sandbox with ledges, spikes, stairs, objects, oil jars, traps, and other things to exploit, you can play this game however you want, because xp (skill points) is awarded through progress rather than kill count, so stealth is viable. As you can see by my hours played, I can affirm to its play value, you'll want to try all the abilities in all sorts of combinations for sure.

All in all, its like oblivion/skyrim but linear and the combat is miles and away more fun (not a E.S. hater), and the perks and locals are far more fleshed out.

Pro tip: with all quests + or - side quests, you can get anywhere between 1 & 1/3rd to 1 & 2/3rds sections of perks filled between the 3 perk lanes (Warrior/combat, Magic, Stealth/misc.)

reviewText:
This is such a great game.  Everything about it is so cool!  I'd place it near the pinnacle of first-person fantasy combat in all three archetypes: melee combat, stealth combat, and wizardry.  The movement is rather unique among fps games in that your character has weight that you can see and feel, and it makes you have to think as you move through combat.  Also, YOU CAN SEE YOURSELF; your body is rendered, and your choice of armor and equipment show.  It looks nice for an older game, and, since it is older, it runs beutifully on a new system.  The atmosphere is excellent, and the story is clever and well paced too.  You even have story changing choices!  Player agency!  I can go on and on about how much I love this game!  The environment is interactive.  The character progression is great, picking perks in the different archetypes: melee sword and sometimes board, Legolas archery, ninja stealth, and powerful sorcery.  You can specialize or mix and match to suit your playstyle.  This adds so much replayability.  I'm playing through again as a Wizard after a cool run as a Warrior type, and I'll go again.   It's such a great game!  Buy it!  Play it!

10/10  Two enthusiastic thumbs up!

This is a gem of fantasy fps gaming.

reviewText:
This review is for the single player, might try the multi-player once I return to land of good internets.

Great game, it might be a bit dated, the physics might be ridiculous at times but it is still well worth playing. And if you are wondering about my hours this is a retail version that I will go for yet another playthrough of soon but I only started using steam properly in the last 2 years and I have this game 8 years or so.

A little history, this is, in essence, the predecessor to dishonored. Yes they are completely different game worlds but it is made by arkane stuidos, the company who also made dishonored and arx fatalis. They don't make many games and there is one thing in common with all of them, the environment is great <--- this is coming from a guy who will rarely even notice, nevermind applaud environment.

If you havent played any of these games then let me give you a quick breakdown.

You play sareth, midevil apprentice to old wizard man who goes on a wonderful adventure filled with swords and spiders and undead creatures playing tag. The story is predicatable and cliché but not badly told.

You being the standard multi-talented rpg character can choose to become the most powerful (headless) warrior/mage/assasin of your time.

So why is the environment so good? Why would I reccomend this at least as much as the much smoother and more polished dishorored? Because you have one of the first games to try realistic physics and while it failed magnificently in some ways, it is still one of the best attempts going. Sure you kick someone within ten yards of a cliff/spikes and they go flying over it after tumbling forever and ever. But alot of objects can be played on both by you and the enemy, even combining in interesting ways with certain spells.

One of the nicest things that is so rare in games is that you REALLY feel different depending on what skills you choose. Stealth is ridiculously OP to the point of breaking the game at stealth 3, while magic only playthroughs are as challenging sub 10 deaths in super meat boy 106%.

The game is completely linear (which I like), even when you make a choice it barely affects any outcomes. Save this guy or not, heres a potion, or a sword, or a chance to kill the annoying one. The most significat differences are the 4 different endings and even there the actual difference is nothing at all, not even really worth exploring.

The enemies are one of the nicer parts, every enemy plays differently. Bigger, smaller, stronger, weaker, come in groups, come alone, have certain elemental weaknesses or can only be hurt in one spot. On the counter side the AI is stupidly exploitable, (this can be fun), but the hardcore player might be very dissapointed.

reviewText:
Dark Messiah of Might & Magic is not a complicated or ambitious game, but what it sets out to do, it does very well... more or less. First, it should be said that like Crusaders of Might & Magic, this is not part of either of the two Might & Magic series (The strategy games and the classic RPGs). While it does take place within that continuity, it plays nothing like them. It does have a level progression system and character building, but more than anything it is a first person corridor shooter, just with swords, bows and magic instead of guns. In fact, the closest thing I can think of is Hexen.

However, while the idea of a melee-oriented FPS may sound questionable (Although consider that Condemned: Criminal Origins came out around the same time), Dark Messiah's combat system is nothing short of fantastic, at least when swords are involved. I highly recommend that any potential players spec melee with just a bit of magic, as the sword fighting system is easily the best part of the game and is what the environments are designed for. Magic, particularly healing, is a nice addition, but focusing on it gets dull. Stealth is just tacked on and serves little purpose. In addition to a number of melee moves, Dark Messiah also features the fantasy version of Duke Nukem's mighty boot, and to be honest, this gets way more use than it should. This is because the levels are liberally covered with spike traps, long falls, fire, and so on that you can punt the enemies into. It's an absolute blast to send an orc falling to his death with nothing but a swift kick, but it does tend to be used far too much. This is because it kicking enemies quickly becomes the most efficient method of dispatching enemies, particularly when fighting a number of enemies in a closed environment.

Overall, the level design is fine, if linear. At certain points, in fact, it could even be called inspired. Like the later Mirror's Edge, platforming is incorporated liberally, and also like that game, you can see the main character's body to help. Rope arrows help you scale the environments and contribute to the sheer numbers of ways you can dispatch your enemies. Towards the end, however, the action moves underground. At this point, most of the environments become incredibly boring, and due to the darkness, most of the game will be played through one of the most obnoxious night vision shaders I've ever seen. Also, while the combat shines when fighting humanoid enemies, this game is way overfond of spider levels, and these bounce between annoying and tedious, depending on how many poison curatives you have. No number of potions, however, can make these sections fun.

The story is entirely forgettable, with absolutely no outstanding characters. While there are multiple endings based on a particular choice, the logic of this choice is simply pathetic. The protagonist, Sareth, is accompanied by two female characters, a young mage and a succubus that lives in his mind, and his persona bounces between boy scout and creepy edgelord depending on which one happens to be the focus of a particular level. Literally no character in this game is particularly interesting or well developed, and the story simply serves to move the action forward.

Dark Messiah is far from perfect, but it has one reason to exist, and that's the combat. At times, the game feels like a spiritual successor to Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast, and that's nothing but a good thing. It isn't as good as Jedi Outcast, but its as close as you'll come. Despite its many flaws, as a combat sandbox Dark Messiah justifies a place in any action gamer's library. However, it should be avoided if you want a well-constructed story, non-linear or open levels, or deep RPG mechanics. Make no mistake, Dark Messiah may look like its contemporary, TESIV: Oblivion, but the two couldn't be more different. Dark Messiah is a competent action game, and if that's all you're in the market for, I recommend it.

reviewText:
This is the first Might and Magic Game I've played. So my review will be based on that.

First of all, THIS GAME IS SHORT. You can probably beat in < 10 hours meaning one day of zoning out on the computer and bam, the final boss is down. The game is divided into 10 chapters with each chapter representing an area. Secondly, this game is as linear as it gets - there is an order for every place and you can't go back - just like FFXIII.

The leveling system is also a bit weird - everything is done in skill points which are obtained by going through the storyline. There are a few optional skill points as well - for finding secret areas or completing optional quests but those are few and far.  You determine your characters class" by spending skill points.

Another thing to note - THERE IS NO TRADING. You can keep items in your inventory
recommended: or drop them. That's it. The only healing you get is either through magic or healing items and mana restoration is only available via mana items which can only be found. So be very careful on how you use what you have.\n\nOn an overall note this game is different

votesHelpful: but it was still fun to play. So if you are looking for something and this game is on sale for under 10 bucks then this may be the game for you.\n\nRATING: 6.5/10."

reviewText:
Hail to the king, baby!

No, it's not Duke Nukem, but the second-most mighty boot in all of gaming.

Join Sareth and companion - his size 12 ♥♥♥♥-kickers - on an adventure to rid the land of evil, carried forth by kicking orcs from ledges, into burning pits, or into plentiful and strategically placed walls of spikes. So much orc kicking even Boromir came back from the dead and shed a tear.

Released in 2006, Dark Messiah takes full advantage of the Source engine, giving us plenty of fun physics to play with. Anything and everything becomes a weapon; whether you throw around crates, push enemies into the path of a swinging chandelier or just make them one with the floor with a well-placed freeze spell. Nine years later, it's a wonder why not more developers have taken advantage of this type of combat system.

The typical RPG archtypes are all here, whether you choose to play as sword and board warrior, dress-wearing wizard, or ♥♥♥♥-ass thief. The skill tree keeps things fresh and gives you some variety as you progress. Unfortunately for the Elder Scrolls fans, there is not enough skill points to allow you to be proficient in everything, meaning you will have to plan your playstyle out in advance and stick with it.

The plot is fleshed out well enough, but won't win any awards in storytelling. The combat is exciting yet frustrating as you load save for the tenth time trying to hack your way through another difficult bottleneck. The multiplayer aspect is unfortunately almost non-existant.

If you've got a few bucks to spend when this game goes on sale, it is a highly worthwhile title worthy of multiple playthroughs.

reviewText:
Fantasy done properly: daggers, swords, bows, magic, creatures, demons, spiders, caves, castles, dragons, orcs, the undead... and bad Demon trying to rule the world.

3 classes, various weapons, various skills - all those allow different approach to combat. Set in fantasy world on a quest to save the world from supreme evil - yeah, standard thing, but does job well. Gameplay is great and combat is very satysfying. Game offers multiple playthroughs (3 classes+skill choices) followed by even more playthroughs due to choices made during story (4 endings). In the end you can beat this game many times and experience something new. If you like fantasy setting and playing as mage/warrior/archer/thief (you can mix classes with skills to create a hybrid character) then it is a good choice. You visit caves, castles, towns - generally areas specific to medieval/fantasy worlds. Levels offer diversity in terms of setting and obstacles as well as approach to combat. Sometiemes they have interesting features that change gameplay or are simply quite original (Big Worm as an example).

It all sounds like a cliche, but the game leaves a very good impression overall. Too bad it was forgotten. Gameplay/Combat is fluid. Surrounding vary and are never boring. It is a very solid title overall. It feels complete and the theme is consistent.

Audio-visuals are strong with this one. Graphics are nice and voice-acting is good. Performance is solid. Music matches the atmosphere.

reviewText: Dark Messiah of Might and Magic was an attempt to branch out the otherwise stagnant Might & Magic franchise, and it should be remembered as one of the better attempts by all of those that played a little of Might & Magic's foray into the real time strategy genre, now that was a bad idea if I ever saw one. It's a Source engine action RPG. Unlike the usual Might & Magic RPGs it takes a much more mainstream approach to just about everything and anybody that's play even a little of modern RPG's will quickly find themselves at ease with the simplicity of it all.\n\nGone are the exploration and everything else that made Might & Magic unique. Only the name and some of the lore remains. Not that I am completely opposed to ignore part of the Might & Magic lore, I was never that excited about the whole space aliens bit. Unfortunately this leaves the game feeling shallow. It's a game that saw what everyone else was doing and thought, Hey
date: me too!".\n\nIn terms of gameplay Dark Messiah is the worlds most premiere kicking simulator. It's an odd thing really
hoursPlayed: skills and magic but you'll find yourself using nothing but your boot to dispatch the vast majority of foes. The harder the difficulty is turned up the easier and more tempting it becomes to kick your enemies into spikes and off ledges simply because it's an instakill maneuver more often than not and your weapons and magic will never be able to match it for damage except in that extremely rare location where there is no environmental hazards to kick enemies into.\n\nThe storyline is fairly decent
voteText:
a little predictable at times but nothing worth complaining about. There is a pretend storyline choice or two that does have a little impact so that helps greatly.

In terms of graphics and sounds it's the source engine and that all comes down to style and Dark Messiah falls squarely into the "Okay" range. Nothing too impressive but nothing that'll ruin your experience either. You'll never be in awe of it but you'll never get annoyed with it either.

The multi-player component is fairly decent although it was always a graveyard so without friends it was impossible to play.

Besides all the kicking Dark Messiah ranks as a not too bad game. It does nothing stellar
votesHelpful: but it does provide a decent enough experience that it's worth it to play through the once. And if you're feeling particularly feisty
votesTotal: you can challenge yourself by making a hard "No-Kicking" playthrough and watch the difficulty skyrocket."

reviewText:
I never played this game back in '06, but I picked it up a few days ago and started on Hardcore difficulty. Immediately I was amazed at how fluid the combat felt for such an old game, even surpassing many recent titles of the past few years. You have different attacks for what you choose - magic, sword, staff, bow or daggers and each have their strengths and weaknesses. You can also block, do finishing blows and kick opponents into traps like fire pits, spike pits and off cliffs.

This is an Action-RPG in first-person perspective. You are within the Might & Magic universe and it is gloriously wicked. Fight spiders, skeletons, ghouls, goblins, trolls, orcs, zombies, dragons, demons. It is insane. Also insanely hard.

You earn skill points to spend on a skill tree, which is where the replayability comes in. There is no new game plus, however I highly recommend you focus on maxing one style of fighting that way you have a reason to play again. I am focusing on upgrading my magic. It is very punishing for mages.

10/10

With today's standards it still holds up. It holds up hard.

reviewText:
Dark Messiah of Might & Magic
Developed by Arkane Studios, the game runs on a modified version of the Source engine; the famed engine that powered Half-Life 2 and its episodes. As much as the world of Ashan is fairly predictable fantasy fare, the game itself plays a lot like your typical Elder Scrolls game.  Physics-based environments are heavily emphasized - far more so than even Bethesda's Oblivion. The puzzles are far better implemented and occur much more often.
That said, beyond the physics, few other comparisons to Oblivion hold water. Unsurprisingly, Dark Messiah sticks to a fairly linear plotline. This is no bad thing since, in the space of twelve lengthy chapters, the pacing rarely wanes and you're never stuck pondering your next objective.


Story:
The story explores the well-trodden, 'recover the mystical artifact for your mentor who may not be all that he seems' scenario. The heroic player, Sareth, is an orphan raised by the mysterious Phenrig. A magician who fuses Sareth with a decidedly kinky guardian entity, Xana, and vests him with a mission to recover te Skull of Shadows.
Of course, like a good book, the story takes a turn for the worse for poor Sareth.

The Sareth/Xana relationship is pretty entertaining. She is effectively a jaded voice in Sareth's head, acting as an occasional hint-giver and guiding him on the path to his objectives. Beyond this, there's her oft-spoken allusions towards rewards of a sexual nature and her constant jealousy of Leanna a Witch in training. She is the obvious love interest whom you'll be spending plenty of quality time with by the end of the game.


Gameplay
It's not surprising in the slightest that the latest iteration of the Might and Magic series draws heavily from multiple sources both book and game alike.
Thankfully, the adoption of a first-person perspective makes for a wholly absorbing experience, and the clever integration of several different skills trees for each class and some unique gameplay features keeps Dark Messiah feeling fresh and genuinely exciting years after the games launch.

Puzzles-wise, many of the game's more thoughtful and interesting moments are cleverly scripted. A rooftop chase sequence early in the game is fast and just precarious enough to be thrilling without becoming aggrovating. In pursuing a scurrying Gollum-like creature in pursuit of a key quest item, you have mere moments to scramble across awnings and through open windows in a deft combination of platforming skills and problem-solving.
Autosaving is very well implemented too - saving at key moments to avoid bouts of severe frustration.


Multiplayer
In addition to the single-player, there's a decent multiplayer mode to Dark Messiah of Might and Magic, and it's fairly different from the campaign. Here, you can choose from different character classes and go into battle via a few different modes. Deathmatch, team deathmatch, and capture the flag all work as expected.

The crusade mode provides a bit more depth than the other modes. This is a humans versus undead mode that uses respawn tickets and control points, similar to something like Warcraft's Arathi Basin battleground or Team Fortress 2's CP_Dustbowl gamemode. The game's multiplayer maps are connected in crusade, so if you win a map, you move one map closer to the opposing team's home base. You also gain experience points and levels in this mode, and each time you level up, you can assign skill points to enhance your abilities like World of Warcraft.
You can switch classes each time you spawn, so if you're tired of clashing swords as a warrior, you can switch to a more projectile-based character, like a mage or an archer. Priestesses can heal and resurrect players, and the assassin acts as a standard MMO stealth character. Experience points carry over from one map to the next, provided you stay connected to the same server.

Sadly, the only way to connect to servers nowadays is by inputing the IP adress into the command console using the Connect" command found in most source games...


Verdict: 9.4 / 10
Dark Messiah of Might & Magic is a decent game
date: it has awesome multiplayer and a decent story filled with content.\nIt may be completed in a matter of 6-12 hours
recommended: but the multiplayer is what has kept the game alive since Launch both on Xbox and on PC."

reviewText:
Having played all the other Might and Magic (M&M) titles (Heroes included) I'm ashamed I haven't played this until today. It's definitely a game that fully deserves to bare the title of a M&M game.

It's a first person RPG very similar to Dragon's Age (DA), obvioulsy this game is much older than DA thus not as polished and big. One thing I would love to have in this game are side quests in open-world manner and more interactivity with random NPCs. Dark Messiah focuses on first person combat and does it wonderfully, whether you decided to use Magic and toast your enemies with fireballs or masterfully slice your enemies with daggers or even go the third route and simply toss boxes, kick enemies into spikes and use various in-game objects to kill them, the combat will make you love this game.

for today's standards in RPG games I rate it 8/10.

reviewText:
In ages past an RPG either distinguished itself by exceptional story or by great customization. Dark Messiah of Might and Magic does neither of those very well, and I doesn't need to.

Dark Messiah's strength is in its gameplay and level-design, its freedom of choice in the completion of challenges set before you. Dark Messiah sports possibly the best melee combat in any First Person game to date and supplements it with a wide variety of environmental interaction.

Impaling your enemies on spikes, chopping their limbs off, burning them to a crisp or making them slip on ice, a smart player has full control over the battlefield. Every approach is viable, every environment suited to take on foes in different and interesting ways. You can master Archery, Melee, Stealth and Magic to become a force to be reckonned with.

Of course nothing comes without flaws and with Dark Messiah it is unfortunately the engine which often crashes or produces (often hillarious) glitches. Still, if you are looking for a game that will challenge your creativity and mastery, this game is for you.

In the realm of content the game provides around 6-8 hours of gameplay time depending on how vigorously you explore the levels and their branching paths and secrets. The story, while nothing to write home about, with a twist telegraphed from miles away, is enjoyable in a corny adventure B-Movie way. Anyone that ever took part in a pen and paper tabletop will enjoy it as a throwback. Furthermore, it never gets in the way, the cinematics are kept to a minimum and never interrupt gameplay for longer than a couple of seconds. Dark Messiah is all about good old fun through gameplay, no carrots on a stick, no grinding and no pretension to be something more than it is.

Don't be fooled, Dark Messiah of Might and Magic might be old, but it is classic worth both your time and the price of admission.

---

reviewText: There's something in the back of my head that says Dark Messiah Might and Magic shouldn't be that good for what it is, but I've played through it multiple times and thoroughly enjoyed it each time. reviewText:
Review by : Meguca
A relatively underappreciated game, Dark Messiah is a first person action rpg running on the Source engine. The ragdolls and physics are as you would expect from a game on the Source engine, with the added fun of dismembering and finishing off your enemies in a multitude of ways. The combat feels exceptionally satisfying, setting it apart from most other fantasy RPGs. Arkane's more well known (and more recent) title, Dishonored, is similar to Dark Messiah in a variety of ways, such as linear levels featuring numerous different paths to the same objective, adding significant replay value. A game worth your time if you enjoy action rpgs.

Follow our Curator page : http://store.steampowered.com/curator/6858371/ This review is written for : The Panda's Corner

reviewText:
Dark Messiah of Might & Magic was a game I had played the demo for at roughly 10 years old. I passed so many hours kicking orcs off of high ledges in the sandbox area provided in the demo and finding it amazing how nice the game looked in comparison to Half Life 2. Recently, with some cash left over from the Winter Sale, I picked up a copy of it and spent two ~7 hour sessions playing through the entirety of the campaign and laughing my ♥♥♥ off.

Describing this game as an RPG feels somewhat disingenious, at least by my definition of an RPG. Those expecting a thorough, immersive high fantasy experience will (probably) be disappointed. If you're looking for some dumb, hack-and-slash, first person sword/magic combat, you'll get exactly what you want. Dark Messiah perfectly blends a mid-2000's E3 FPS tech demo and a hack-and-slash RPG. Kicking orcs, goblins, guards, and ghouls around is immensely satisfying. Hell, the sword-and-board combat itself feels nice and meaty. While I didn't focus on it too much, and only placed a few points into magic abilities, they do feel a bit lackluster, but Telekinesis is endless fun. Overall, the game makes up for its few faults by being immensely satisfying, fun, and rewarding

A word of warning, however. While now nearly ten years old, Dark Messiah is admittedly dated. Running on the 2004 version of the Source Engine, (I believe, at least, I know that it certainly isn't running on the Orange Box engine,) patch after patch has made the game a bit unstable. I experienced about 15 crashes between these two sessions, but considering the game's now low requirements, getting back into the game is just a minor inconvenience, this along with the rapid climb in difficulty will ensure you're saving quite frequently. There are a few things that don't quite play as well as they did in the unpatched, 2006 version of the game, one of my major gripes being the few boss fights speckled throughout the campaign. Some of them just are not particularly fun from a gameplay perspective, but luckily are few and far between.

Altogether, my run of Dark Messiah: Might and Magic came out to about 12 hours or so, playing on Hard. I imagine the game can range from about 5-20 hours depending on your difficulty and speed of play. Overall, if you enjoy physics combat gimmicks and kicking orcs off large cliffs, and generally just 'running up on fools,' and don't mind some early Source Engine jank, Dark Messiah is a game for you.

reviewText:
Dark Messiah of Might & Magic is the epitome of what underrated games are. Arkane Studios did a fantastic job creating this game where you can choose between play styles such as mage, warrior, rogue, archer, and class combinations (archer+rogue or mage+rogue) depending on what talents you choose.
The overall story of DM is rather unique and is exactly what a fantasy story is meant to be with backstabs included for half-price and even cheesy romance. Many of the situations that the story will place you in are smoothly transitioned and are an absolute blast to play in. For example, in one level you awaken to soldiers invading your dwelling and kill the housekeeper who comes to warn you of the danger. This immediately puts you in a state of alert to fight for your life. That scenario is all done perfectly whilst blended with narrative that exquisitely blends what people want in gameplay with storytelling.
Combat within DM is fun, what more can be said? Kicking. I could say kicking. But yes the kicking element of DM is absolutely amazing where you'll boot orcs off bridges miles in the air, sending them plummeting to their doom. The game could even teach TES game a thing or two about swordplay where you have to swing your blade PAST their guard. And while it'll be easy at first, it'll intensify against enemies that are far better at blocking and attacking. Magic is a fresh step in the right direction and it all feels right. Magicking and shooting a massive fireball feels good and so does zapping humans with lightning bolts. Likewise every other combat option is just as satisfying (such as bow&arrow where you have to aim a little above your target to get the bolt to aim true, also staves)
The graphics have aged quite well for this game and I've nothing bad to say of the soundtrack (or good in that matter).

Sadly the largest fault of the game has to be the lack of AI smarts in your oppnents AT TIMES. I think Arkane Studios did a great job at creating good AI, but if you happen to swing a large chandelier back and forth, you'll find enemies constantly killing themselves over jumping into an obvious death machine. I'd hope most people would agree that it's hard (if not impossible) to have designed an enemy AI over whatever is happening in the environment at the time of the game's creation.

I'd heavily recommend this game to anyone who hasn't played this, it's enormous fun for the first run or two through.

reviewText:
Something for all your nefarious (kicking) needsI never knew this game existed until I found it by chance one day ago. Thought I'd pick it up, because it looked interesting, I gathered that the melee combat was good, and I'm currently very curious about first-person melee combat.

Nine hours later, it was already evening. I'd binged through most of the whole thing, and had to stop only because of biological needs and because my eyes were stinging. Rarely have I seen them be so bloodshot...

This game comes quite close to what I'd like to make, if I had a team of artists at my disposal. The graphics are very pretty, though of course, the game is ten years old at the time of writing of this review, and beauty is in the eyes of the beholder. Still, the HDR lighting in particular makes an astonishing difference, and the whole things looks really nice at maximum quality.

The story is... adequate. It's certainly nothing groundbreaking, and I had a feeling that I've already played this game, despite the fact that I never have. That may have been a result of the story.
It's worth mentioning that this game feels like some sort of Tomb Raider mixed with the new Thief game (the one from 2014). The protagonist is a gluttonous kleptomaniac with a berry juice addiction, who spends most of his time raiding tombs. Aside from that, we've got demon kings, ancient artefacts, necromancer armies... and, of course, all of it ended with a dragon, as is standard for the budget fantasy genre.
It really does remind me of a budget fantasy film... But I really love that sort of thing, so I enjoyed it.
I should also say that the big twist" of the story actually caught me by surprise. I wasn't expecting that to happen.

It's also got a voiced protagonist (though no dialogue choices)

reviewText:
Definately not a traditional Might and Magic game, this first-person boot-of-awesome simulator is an enjoyable game. While the multiplayer is pretty lame, the singleplayer campaign is interesting enought that a run or two through can prove to be enjoyable, especially when your epic boot of ragdolling is introduced into the mix.

A simple kick forward can result in enemies stumbling back into various hazards such as fire or spikes, all of which are amazingly hilarious to use.

A mediocre game, but still enjoyable to those that won't take it seriously and don't have strong ties to the Might and Magic series.

reviewText: It's easy to see why people enjoy Dark Messiah of Might & Magic so much. The gameplay, although linear, is pretty impressive once you get into any form of combat. The combat in Dark Messiah not only involves just magic and basic weapons, but also the enviroment; thus making any fight pretty creative. Want to kick someone into the spikes? Go for it. Want to knock someone off a balcony? Have at it. Want to hit someone so hard that they get closelined by a wooden beam, thus causing them to flip and land on their neck? This game allows you to do that.\n\nDark Messiah is a crowd pleaser. Definitely pick up this title.

reviewText:
Wonderful game. Freaking amazing.

10/10.

Pros:
*Awesome combat.
*Awesome visuals.
*Awesome immersion.
*Awesome soundtrack.

Cons:
...

A flawlessly executed game, Dark Messiah is a gem where it's amazing in all aspects. The combat is fun and allows for diverse play styles, letting you focus on warrior, rogue, or mage, and giving you the ability to combine and mix them all. Exploration is rewarding and there's a lot of neat secret areas and rewards for you to find. The story is solid and interesting, with a really satisfying ending... depending on what you do.

reviewText:
Intro:
Dark messiah does not feel like a linear adventure game with their backpack and level system. It's more like an FPS/RPG(I woudlnt say action rpg).

Longevity and difficulty:
It does not take too many hours to beat it, but it's worth it. Play at very hard and i bet you won't survive. I tried it on hard mode, but you still have to limit yourself if you want your hard mode to be challenging.

Limit yourself(a game is never too hard):
So if you want your hard to be hard, you should not unlock healself and do not use weapons that do exactly what a spell does unless you want to do a quick speedrun. At the very least, drop the ice bow and lighting shield.

Combat:
One of the best combat system. The enemies and the ai are strong and smart enough to beat you in a duel. so imagine when 2 of them jumps on you. This forces you to sneak first before you engage. It forces you to use you spells strategically to kill a couple before you jump on the last few of the room to kill. Thus, it forces you to use your environment and front kicking your opponent on a spike like a mortal kombat's fatality. Speaking of fatalities, you will most likely kill your opponent with a fatal blow and you must build up your meter for that like a super meter from street fighter.

Story:
Il say it now, don't play for the story. The immersion is there and everything, but the story is not that good. The ending is one of the worse.

Verdict: Buy the game. It's unique and this game probably influenced most first person slashing games after that. It was very unique when it came out in 2006 and it still feels that way.

reviewText:
A very primitive source engine game that does a pretty good job dealing with the limitations of said engine. It's a very linear rpg. There's not a lot of side stuff to do. A few optional things that will grant you more skill points/different ending, that's all. I really enjoyed it because it has everything I need in a RPG without the padded filler. The story was interesting, and some of the characters are pretty memorable (your psycho♥♥♥♥♥ guide). Music is kind of forgettable.

The combat is where most of the fun comes from. It feel right. The impact of some of the swings, the kicks(which you will be doing a lot), and some of the traps look realistically painful. The physics are wonky, but this is early source. Just kick the ♥♥♥♥ out of those damn goblins and send them flying off a cliff. There's not much loot, but the loot you get looks pretty badass.

reviewText: I admit, Dark Messiah came as sort of a surprise for me. Absolutely fantastic level design that actually supports all three viable play styles (combat-magic-stealth) in equal measure, and first-person melee combat which is still one of the best ever made combined with lack of incessant hand holding inherent to video games these days - all come together in one amazing package that's only somewhat tarnished by its wonky AI and, at times, signature Source Engine animation clunkiness. Also, chewing the scenery" doesn't even BEGIN to describe game's voice acting."

reviewText: This is an impressive title with a new take on fist person gameplay. You can choose an emphasis for your skills, and develop it further, or branch out. You can sneak, fight with swords, or become an expert in the arcane. The story is interesting, compelling, and immerses you in a detailed world with crazy twists and lots of excitement. This is one heck a good ride, and one I want to ride again and again just to experience all the possible outcomes. A definite buy if you like to decide your own fate in a classic mideval setting surrounded by fantasy staples like orcs and goblins.

reviewText:
HEY, PALLL!!!

This game is the resultant offspring between the brief Ubisoft/Source relationship of 2006. What you get from this incident is a unique RPG/action/adventure game in terms of both combat and gameplay. Using the 3 styles of playthroughs provided (Sword-fighting, Magic, or Stealth) there are plenty of fun and creative ways to dispatch foes using finesse, might, or dumb luck. The campaign itself is fairly linear and the story is nothing to remember but the gameplay is so different from anything I've played prior that I can't find another, more popular, comparison to give. There is replayability provided from the multiple play styles which are worth trying out and finally it should be noted that this game can't be taken too seriously; though it wants to be. The laughable voice acting and derpy A.I. make playing it way too enjoyable and hilarious for the purpose of a serious story-backed game. In short, I recommend this unique specimen if on sale and you don't mind a casual and funny action/adventure experience.
(Also, the women seem to try way too hard to get your attention in this one… and it’s still cheesy as ever)

reviewText: I still occasionally play this game after ten years. I'd say it's one of my favorite single player games. Yeah the storie's pretty generic and cliche (like, 95% cliche), but it's not bad necessarily. It's still interesting and far from dull. The melee combat is a lot of fun, especially for a game from 2006, and it still holds up today. The game's a little bit buggy at times but the only persisting issue is when you try to use the Rope Bow in small spaces, as it can make you glitch into walls. Magic seems a little underpowered, in my opinion, while the Warrior path seems quite overpowered, even on the Hardcore difficulty. Consider a bow-focused Hardcore Assassin playthrough if you want the most challenging of the three (or four) classes". It's fairly long with a fun selection of weapons and a rather limited but sufficient choice in armor. AI's not super amazing but for a 2006 game it suffices. Overall
date: I wish the game got more attention than it did; it certainly deserved it
recommended: and the reviews are pretty unfair

reviewText:
I played this game before it came on Steam, and I had a blast.

I bought this game when it came out on Steam, and I have been having a hell of a good time all over again. It's not the most gorgeous game, it's about on-par with Half-Life 2 (fun fact: they're on the same engine). The RPG elements aren't the most deep, and skill points are gained at set points throughout the game, some of which are missable. The story is entirely ignorable.  Weapons and armor are only acquired through finding them in the world. It's mostly linear.

But you can kick people off cliffs. You can kick people into fires and watch as they struggle to limp over to a source of water before you kick them in and kill them while they're down. You can kick people into spikes. You can kick people into weak structural supports, causing barrels and boxes and whatnot to fall onto their allies, killing them. Your kick is one of the greatest weapons of all time, and it is unbelievably satisfying to use throughout the entire game. I've never had so much fun with first-person fantasy combat in my life.

I give it 4/5 kicks. Buy this game.

reviewText:
I just recently got this game again after having played through it on the disc version back in 2007. Jumping back in, it certainly holds up, as it was fairly ahead of its time when it was released (in some ways more than Oblivion). Whether you are new to the developer Arkane, enjoyed their most recent game, Dishonored, or like me have been loving their style since Arx Fatalis, you will have a lot to enjoy for a low price.

PROS: Graphics still looking fairly good thanks to the Source Engine, maxing out with ease on my modest rig. Enemy encounters are varied and enjoyable, plenty of options in how to take out baddies (magic, bows, blades, environmental kills). The story is pretty interesting and has pacing that keeps you engaged, taking you to some great locations. Large amounts of nostalgia if you've played before. Kicking an orc into an abyss is super satisfying.

CONS: Scripted events can feel pretty obvious at times. Voice acting and characters are a bit cheesy (though I enjoy them). Combat is generally satisfying, but sometimes you don't connect when you feel you should. Weapon and enemy types are somewhat limited.

Overall I'd rate this game an 8/10

reviewText:
I never really gave Dark Messiah a chance back when it was first released. I bought it, played it for maybe 10 minutes and then closed it. I don't know why, because I started playing this again recently and it was pretty good for a game released in 2006. The graphics still hold up (well, mostly) to this day and the gameplay works alright as well, with some minor flaws. These flaws aren't actually flaws at all. It's just that we've been spoiled with games that do most of these 'flaws' better. For example, walking around, and especially jumping over obstacles, feels very wooden. Same goes for the combat. Switching between weapons and spells isn't as fluent when compared to, let's say, Skyrim. Now I can't fault a 6 year old game for not being up-to-date, but it does throw you out of the experience from time to time.
I really should've played this earlier, because it was seriously pretty good.
I do wonder if Bulletstorm got its inspiration from this game though... ?

[Rating: 80/100]

reviewText: Dark Messaih of Might and Magic takes a big risk by portraying the Messiah (Jesus Christ of Nazareth) as a sword-wielding, orc-slaying dealer of justice, but the game immediately draws you in to the empire of Ur-Bethelehem, where Jesus has found himself transported after detonating a Holy Trinity Device in a last-ditch attempt to keep Satan from fusing with the Tree of Knowledge of Good and Evil, which would have given him control over morality. Jesus quickly adapts to this fantasy environment, and after taming a dragon, you will spend much of your time freeing the populace from the dominion of the evil Pharisees, led by a mirror-universe clone of Judas, Jesus' closest ally back in the true world. Although the game overuses your ability to turn water into wine and raise the dead, it's a very strong game overall, and by the time Jesus is telling a newly-decapitated orc let he who is without a head cast the first spell
date: you'll be happy you bought this game.

reviewText:
Embrace the power of the Dark Side! Back in the days, this title was a good example of a well-crafted action RPG created with Source Engine. It was both gameplay-rich and storytelling-wise, with a tech potential of the Source engine at it's finest for that time period.

It's not an open-world game, but it does give you a choice. You have a choice to craft your own hero, choosing your path through the storyline set in one of the HoMM worlds. You could become a powerful wizard and unleash doom at your foes or stick to the shadows and play with prey. Or you could pick an axe, and start to wreck everything in your way in blazing havoc. Choice is yours.

I recommend this game for all fantasy fanboys out there because it's now the living classics and it'll totally be worth your time. It's missing Steamworks features, though, but I wonder how nice would have been an HD remaster!

reviewText:
A first-person hack n' slash RPG made by a bunch of people who had the balls to try something a bit different, and in my opinion succeeded for the most part. It won't hold your hand and you will start off under-powered and fighting uphill for a long while. However, this means that when you're hacking off heads left and right in the late-game and the characters comment on your growth in power, you actually understand what they mean.

The combat is one of the best parts of the game - the swordplay is fairly intuitive, the shield blocks effectively, and there's no weapon or armour degradation getting in the way of fun gameplay. Also, once you work out how to score a headshot with the bow, stealth attacks become fun and effective. Yes, there's a bit of kicking - kicking people off ledges or into spikes or down stairs, but I didn't feel I was oversaturated with this option and I felt that it aided me when I needed it.

It is, however, somewhat baffling that a game operating under the 'Might and Magic' umbrella railroads you into choosing the 'might' path over magic on more than one occasion. I feel sorry for the poor sod who threw all his experience points into spells, and then has to fight the orc warlord under the condition of 'no spells'. The fight is hard enough as it is without having to battle his 5 cronies at the same time while awkwardly switching from one spell to another as you can't equip more than one spell at a time.

Similarly, to utilise armours (of which there are 3 very specific types - warrior, stealth, and mage armours) the game forces you to level very specific traits up. Meaning that you are, once again, railroaded into making certain skill choices which makes you realise that the game would be the same if they'd simply asked you if you wanted to be a warrior, assassin or mage at the start and that the concept of organic skill choice in this game is mostly an illusion.

That said, I'm talking a lot about little niggly things - overall I had a lot of fun, and the game does allow a fair degree of freedom when it comes to your choices in the story, so I would highly recommend it, especially for a sale price.

PROS:
* Responsive and fun combat that utilises the environment well and genuinely provides a varied and free experience.
* The texture detail is quite good and I felt the Source engine was used to good effect.
* A story you can actually follow.
* The difficulty can be genuinely challenging, forcing you to think rather than just hack about.

CONS:
* Occasionally frustrating platforming elements.
* The characterisations of the women are grating, as they constantly fawn over you in what seems to be rather creepy wish-fulfillment for the developers.
* Those that like to be a jack-of-all-trades will be disadvantaged.
* The difficulty can be frustratingly punishing, resulting in multiple restarts because of tiny errors.

reviewText:
Awesome sword and sorcery game that you'll love restarting again and again just to experience diferent combat oportunities.
The game offers opportunities for physics driven traps and contraptions, platforming, exploration and stealth. The rope arrows are the most amusing thing to use when you're not trying to kill the enemies in diferent and creative ways. You'll reach places you would have though unreachable in other games and find that the devs left a few items there. You'll find yourself often sourounded and runing around trying to throw objects to stun or trip your enemies, often pulling them over a fire or a breakable platform, pushing them under a heavy pillar or swinging trap.
did i mention you have a key dedicated to kick, just like in Duke Nukem but in a better way i think.

I just wish the game would go on and on forever as i tend to finish it too quickly. Too bad they never released any modding tools for it even though it uses the Source engine (Half Life 2).

reviewText:
Underrated. A title that flew under the radar because of the Might and Magic name. Too different for traditional RPG fans but action-adventure fans weren't lured either, thinking it's probably just another RPG.

It also suffers because the intro is extremely dark and the combat, while not overly complicated, does have a bit of a learning curve.  I think the opening tutorial might have turned off a lot of players right out of the gate.  However, once the main story begins the atmosphere of the game changes completely and draws you in.

Fun melee action or combo'ing spells with melee.  Tons of environmental use like kicking bad guys off cliffs or dropping stuff on their heads.

It's pretty linear but done the right way, including varied environments and mini bosses, and it's all tightly coupled to the story so you don't feel like you're playing just another filler level that pads the running time.

Graphically the game is starting to look dated but required very high end hardware in its day to max out, so consequently still looks quite good on modern hardware.  At the usual $5 price these days it's definitely worth it.

reviewText:
This is one of my favorite games ever, and arguably the one that has the best 1st person swordplay action to date, including The Elder Scroll series, Chivalry, War of the Roses and the like.

There's three basic classes: Warrior, Wizard and Thief. This sounds restrictive at first, but apart from the fact that you can play the entire game 3 times and get a totally different experience out of it every time depending on your class, you can also just distribute your level-up points in all three skill trees as you see fit and mix it up. Even for a warrior, it's pretty useful to be able to turn enemies against each other or to spot traps or hidden doors; Even for a mage, it's useful to do more damage with your staff or sneak around more effectively, and even for a thief/assassin, it's useful to be able to disarm enemies or create magic invisible fire traps.

The story is cool and intriguing with a couple of big optional choices and side missions that affect it, the locations beautiful and diverse (although the graphics are a little outdated, of course), exploration and sneaking fun and immersive, boss fights pretty unique and against several pretty BIG enemies, the RPG mechanics balanced and the fights badass and VERY satisfying - and this is the meat of the game.
You can disarm foes, dismember them, burn them, shrink them, zap them, freeze them, stealthkill them, kick them into spikes and fires or off cliffs or into other enemies and use the environement in all kinds of other creative ways (cut/shoot ropes to have large objects drop on or swing at enemies, or to collapse bridges or pillars to crush enemies, create fire arrows by simply holding an arrow into any fire, and shooting into oil puddles or at enemies directly - sometimes after you picked up an oil pot and threw it in their face for that extra-crispiness. You can of course use firespells for that, too.). The cool implementation of the environment into the combat always has you looking for opportunities at any location, which makes both planning fights from the shadows and thinking on your feet in hairy combat situations a lot of fun, and you feel like a proper badass after a huge fight that was so awesome that it could have been featured in a movie. This game makes you feel badass, and you feel like you EARNED to feel badass.
Enemies include humans, goblin and orcs (warriors, archers or wizards of all sorts), zombies and skeletons, quasi-dragons, spiders, trolls and more, and they often require different tactics.
Oh, and you get *SLIGHT SPOILER ALERT, SORT OF (because you can set change form" in the key bindings anyway)* the ability to turn into an "Alien"-like demon form later on
hoursPlayed: if you're into that sort of thing...*END OF ZOMG SPOILER*\n\nYou'll also do a lot of freeclimbing with the ability to grab ledges and the use of chains and ropes (You get Thief-style rope arrows later on

reviewText: Ok, before people start bashing this game for the admittedly terrible voice acting and lame plot, consider what this game does. It is an action RPG that focuses on being smarter and more skilled than the NPCs. Sure, you could charge at an enemy and beat them to death with your sword; OR, you could shoot them with your bow, crush them with collapsable scaffolding, drop them down a pit, down some stairs, hit them with barrels, kick them into spikes, burn them, kick them into each other, or stab them in the back. The level up system is kinda lackluster, and does seem like it takes forever to get some useful skills. If you RPG damage sponges want a game that doesn't require much thought to play, by all means, don't buy this game. If you are looking for an RPG that challenges you on multiple levels and prefer gameplay to plot and VAs, give this a shot. A good plot does not make a bad game better, but a bad story doesn't hinder a good game.
