reviewText:
The M&M series is primarily either an old-school, pen-and-paper style dungeon crawler, or a card game. Meanwhile, Dark Messiah is an oddity; it's a first-person action RPG in the Source engine, of all things! Picture Half-Life 2 with swords and sorcery instead of guns and robots, and you'll have a good idea of what this game plays like. Going into this title, I did not expect much. I knew it was from Arkane Studios, the same folks who delivered the excellent Dishonored, but all the same I was not prepared to fall in love with the game.

The Story
Most certainly Dark Messiah's weakest aspect. You play as Sareth, an apprentice serving under the wizard Menelag. Your master has sent you to deliver some sort of artifact to a friend in a far off city, but has transported a woman into your conciousness to be your guide for mysterious reasons. Xana is pretty much a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ version of Cortana from Halo. You'll either tolerate her character, or outright despise her. Once you actually get to your destination, stuff hits the fan and you're thrust into a campaign to defeat an evil Necromancer. There are quite a few plot twists along the way. The biggest will probably be obvious to you, but I can guarantee there are plenty of left-field ones. The question is... will you even care enough to, well, care about what happens? 6/10

The Gameplay
Ahhh, now here's Dark Messiah's shining beacon of awesomeness. I'm going to be blunt about this one, straight out of the gate: Dark Messiah has the greatest first-person combat I've experienced in a game. The guys at Arkane are wizards when it comes to first-person animations; everything is incredibly silky smooth and satisfying to witness and interact with. As you progress through the game, you'll be rewarded Skill Points which you can then distribute as you please through two skill trees. There's no skill that will drastically change up how you play; just some generic More HP" or "Slightly Bigger Fireball". Still
date: it works. You can also get some skill points by finding certain secret objectives within the world.\n\nDark Messiah's level structure is not unlike Doom or Quake... Littered with clever secrets (Some I didn't find until my fifth or so playthrough!) filled with special loot like new armors and weapons. Using either a Sword & Shield
voteText: Bows
votesHelpful: you'll slice and dice and stab and smash and burn and freeze and electrocute your way through hordes of Mercenaries
commentsCount: Undead
column16: and more. Though you can mash your attack button
column17: that is rarely effective. The true combat is found using the various styles of power attacks. Not unlike the system found in Elder Scrolls
column18: you'll preform different attacks based on which direction you are moving. From vertical swipes to long reaching stabs to hard-hitting slashes
column19: you'll need to use every available move to defeat the very clever Orcs later on. Swords are nimble; the all-around weapon. They're capable of parrying foes
column20: and you can even disarm by power-attacking while aiming at the hand. Daggers are lightning fast. They chop up foes before they can get a swing in
column21: and they are capable of instant kills against unaware and fleeing enemies. Staves lack damage
column22: but in smart hands they are the most powerful in the game. They can strike multiple foes at once
column23: and blows to the head almost always stun instantly
column24: leaving the foe extremely vulnerable to being kicked off their feet and into traps and the like. Bows work like you'd expect; headshots instantly kill unaware enemies. Once you get the skill that makes you draw faster and a secret unlimited quiver
column26: most definitely.\n\nMagic requires a lot of skill to use effectively. Sure
column27: you have your standard fireballs and lightning bolts and freeze spells
column28: but in my experience it is just too difficult to use solely these in combat. You'll need to be crafty; turn enemies against each other with a mind-control spell
column29: shrink enemies to the size of mice
column30: and lay traps near instant-killing spike-walls in the environment.\n\nAbout a third of the way through the game
column31: you'll find the Rope Bow. Truly an inventive tool that I would adore seeing in another game. Near useless in combat
column32: this weapon is instead used to navigate the environment; firing at any wooden structure above you will release a dangling rope you can climb and jump from! This one simple tool drastically changes up the level structure from there-on
column33: and gives room for some dastardly secret nooks and crannies.\n\nAdmittedly
column34: it does take quite a while to get used to how the game works. But I guarantee you... when it all clicks
column35:
you'll be saying "Holy smokes! This is gosh-dang-diddly-dum AWESOME!" 10/10

The Art and the Sound
If you've seen any sort of high fantasy movie
column39: you've seen everything in Dark Messiah before. There's nothing visually that is truly original or outstanding. Admittedly
column40: the super weapons later on have some great designs and one of the final levels is a big palette cleanser after hours of trudging through a boring ol' cave system. The environment
column41: the enemies... it's all generic as possible. Thankfully
column42: the sound is a fair bit better. The clang of metal against metal and swooshes of air as swords tear through it are top-notch and really bring a little extra bit of immersion. You'll probably get sick fast of the early Mercenary enemies who seem to always begin a fight with "Hey
column44:
but the later gruffness of Orcs and Goblins and the like feel a fair bit more threatening. 8/10

The Replayability
Between the many different styles of equipment available
column45: the extremely harsh skill point limit
column46: and the myriad of secrets to be found in every corner
column47: you'll definitely want to play this beast more than once. The average first playthrough will probably take 12-15 hours. There are multiple endings
column48:
but trust me; you won't be replaying just to see these. The addictiveness of the combat is far more a reason to do so than the plot. 9/10

In Summary
Dark Messiah came out in 2006
column49: and I played it in 2014. I was WOWed by it
column50:
and found myself playing it over five times before getting bored. I legitimately count it among one of my favorite games now. Well worth the low price of admission these days!

Story: 6/10
Gameplay: 10/10
Art and Sound: 8/10
Replayability: 9/10
Total: 8.3/10"

reviewText:
Dark Messiah is one of those games that I enjoyed immensely but people in general seemed to dislike. It probably doesnt do the other Might and Magic games justice (I wouldn't know), but it is a solid game in itself with good melee combat (for me, probably the best yet), agreeable graphics and lots of fun places to explore.

The game lets you pick your own path and places to reach with its lovable rope-arrows, which -for those that have played them- works exactly like the rope arrows in Thief 1 & 2. The exploration is encouraged by the game designers and you will often find awesome stuff (like a homage to the Thief series as an example) lying about in crazy places.

So if you are an old Thief Fan that love exploration and getting to places you werent mean to be in(tm), this is probably a game for you. If youre just on the lookout for some fantasy melee (or range/magic) action with optional stealth, this is also probably a game for you.

Just dont abuse the kick, it spoils the fun.

reviewText: There is an unusually large discrepancy for this game in regards to the critic versus consumer level reviews. It's a fantastic game where, when faced with several appointments at once, the primary factor in your survival is how foolhardy you are. Do you have audacity? Often it's your only chance, but it'll be your downfall too. To me, that's how being surrounded by a group of armed men should feel. Systematically killing them doesn't make sense - either you manage to immediately try to shift  the odds more in your favor somehow or you're dead. Throwing pots, ropes, kicking, pushing, trying  oh so desperately not to get flanked, other? I've only played two other games that are satisfying in this regard (on Hard at least). Dishonored (made by the developers of Dark Messiah) and Chivalry: Medieval Warfare. Winning when you're attacked by other players 3v1 in Chivalry feels absolutely fantastic. But anyways, as far as PvE combat goes, Dark Messiah is great. The story line isn't fantastic, it's not a free roaming RPG, and you might like to make more RPG choices. But the game has excellent combat, a comfortably earthy fantasy tone, and the level design is good (with the exception of too many spikes wall things - too many damn spikes).

There's not a lot of exploring to do. Some
date: but not much. There are secret places you might not find
recommended: but they rarely contain anything really valuable (just a couple extra potions usually). The graphics are pretty
voteText: really cool.\n\nThe one bad thing is that you spend in-game time to perform meta-game tasks. For example

reviewText: I would say this is one of the best action based rpg's out there, it's my personal favorite next to Fable, and even better than Oblivion and Skyrim, the combat system is better and the level system and skill tree is more enjoyable as well..... The only complaints I had was that it felt short and the ending of the story was strangely abrupt, but the shortness of the game is easily made up by it's re playability of different skill trees and different difficulty settings. The game also has a multiplayer and it's fun but there is rarely anyone that plays.  It's one of my favorites because leveling systems and combat mechanics for me is really important as opposed to the Elder Scrolls series which seems to skip over that, like I said it's kind of like a WoW version of Fable, if your into orcs and dragons and a fun leveling system than you wont regret getting this.

reviewText: Don't be confused by the name. This is no turn-based RPG. It's first-person action all the way with just a sprinking of RPG progression.\n\nDark Messiah's single player has been the only first-person shooter" I've played that brought back memories of the old Jedi Knight games. It's not just a rollicking adventure
date: but it offers very distinct playstyles. The stealth mechanics are good enough to satisfy a fan of the Thief games. Some of the spells are brutal and make you feel like a truly powerful mage. And those who prefer fighting will enjoy the novel-yet-effective experience of throwing furniture at enemies and kicking them off edges or into spikes.\n\nGet this game if you're missing over-the-top shooters of old
recommended: like Jedi Knight or Duke Nukem
hoursPlayed: or if you liked the combat in Skyrim but longed for something MORE."

reviewText:
A first-person action/adventure game which eschews player levels for skill points awarded based on progress through the game rather than kills (except bosses). Allows combinations of the three combat styles common in games (warrior, rogue, mage), but the more skillful player will use their environment to greatest advantage.

The world is littered with physics objects which may be used to hurt, disorient, trip, or impale your enemies. Shove your foes into the fire, or use oil to bring the fire to them. If they are foolish enough to wander near a high ledge, give them a kick and let gravity do the work for you. Take advantage of traps or unsafe building equipment, which could hurt them just as well as you.

If you're not the type to get your hands dirty, charm the most powerful foe and watch them fight amongst each other. Or sneak by them, you need not be the grim reaper in this world, as foes are merely obstacles in your path, not the goal.

Would you embrace your destiny or fight it?

I don't understand why some people think that a linear story is always a bad thing. Its simply a different style. The biggest benefit is that the developers get to focus on each part more, making a more involved and polished experience.

reviewText: Of course this is no RPG like TES, with an open world, individual characters and free decisions - but it still is one of the best I've ever had the pleasure to play. On the one hand, it has a nice combat system: making use of your environment and physics. On the other hand, and that's the more important part, because of its atmosphere and story. No other game or even movie could ever give me such intense feelings of solitude, claustrophobia and doom. The spider level was the most horrible experience of my gaming life. It's a great thing when a game can cause actual emotions like that in a player.

reviewText:
What drew me into Dark Messiah was that it seemed like an Elder Scrolls clone without the massive time commitment. In my days of youth, I recall repeatedly playing the demo. When I finally got my hands on a full copy of this game, I was more than enthused to take it for a spin.

Dark Messiah boasts a wonderful melee combat system and forces the player to think tactically. Rushing into a room with even two or three enemies will result in certain death. As you level up, you can invest points into your typical RPG attributes: melee, ranged, magic, and stealth combat. Diversity and replayability are certainly present.

Unfortunately, the game's difficulty encourages cheap tactics such as kicking enemies over ledges or into traps, resulting in instant kills. The user interface is occasionally unresponsive, making switching weapons or casting spells a royal pain. Furthermore, mages will also find themselves lacking enough hotkeys to fit arsenal.

This is a bargain bin game.

Grade: C

reviewText:
Still possibly the best combat system in anything resembling an RPG. Dishonored owes every good thing about its combat to Dark Messiah. I think it still compares favorably with Dark Souls - it's less methodical and has less variety than Dark Souls, but the core hacking, slashing, maneuvering and spellcasting is cleaner.

This game is worth it just to use the console to spawn enemies to fight over and over again. The combat is that good. Block and parry. clash swords, and dismember enemies with power strikes. Use the amazing kick  to impale them on spikes or through weakened pillars. Lure enemies through swinging physics-based environmental traps, or cast an ice spell on the ground to send them slipping off a cliff.

Please someone make a co-op version of at least the combat in this game.

reviewText:
What drew me into Dark Messiah was that it seemed like an Elder Scrolls clone without the massive time commitment. In my days of youth, I recall repeatedly playing the demo. When I finally got my hands on a full copy of this game, I was more than enthused to take it for a spin.

Dark Messiah boasts a wonderful melee combat system and forces the player to think tactically. Rushing into a room with even two or three enemies will result in certain death. As you level up, you can invest points into your typical RPG attributes: melee, ranged, magic, and stealth combat. Diversity and replayability are certainly present.

Unfortunately, the game's difficulty encourages cheap tactics such as kicking enemies over ledges or into traps, resulting in instant kills. The user interface is occasionally unresponsive, making switching weapons or casting spells a royal pain. Furthermore, mages will also find themselves lacking enough hotkeys to fit arsenal.

This is a bargain bin game.

Grade: C

reviewText:
Dark Messiah has been out for more than a few years now, but the game still provides a solid single-player experience. The story may not be that engaging, but the combat is fun and allows you to finish the game in a number of ways: you can either develop yourself as an assassin, a mage, just go for a hardcore berserker approach or develop for some sort of hybrid. The nice thing is that all of these feel like they are actually viable and fun options.

The game was based on the Source engine, meaning it also uses the physics made popular by Half-Life 2 to its fullest, admittedly even going a little overboard on it sometimes (or those orcs sure love having dem dere spikey racks all over the place). The use of the Source engine also means that Dark Messiah´s graphics have aged quite well.

All in all, a good 8/10.

reviewText: Good game at a good price. First, it's not open like Oblivion. But the degree of polish and detail is something you can't find in a massive world game. You can build your character as you like, and there are always many routes to take to complete the objectives. Single-player has a good story, and really breaks from the cliche RPG stories. Multiplayer has great potential, as you can improve skills by completing tasks. Combat is excellent in all aspects, and I recommend the game.

reviewText: What I liked about Dark Messiah was the fear of the enemy's attack when on the hardest settings.  I found myself running away from enemies all the time.  Seeing them at the end of corridors freaked the hell out of me.  I didn't have enough upgrades most of the time.  Enemies were too powerful.  At times, I thought maybe going on hardest was a bad idea.  I did finish it though.  At long last.  It felt great.\n\nThe settings were beatiful and you had that feeling of dread when you were near or in the presence of evil.  This is a really good but somewhat flawed example of a first person melee fantasy game.  Way better than any other game in its time.  it was too bad they didn't continue supporting this game like other Source Engine powered games.  I would have loved to re-visit Might and Magic in first person.

reviewText: MM Dark Messiah is one of the most forgotten and unappreciated gems in the role-playing genre. The game breaks from the classic Might & Magic style from a long open world rpg to a linear action focused rpg and it does so beautifully. The game is short for a rpg lasting only 6 hours or so, but in that time you will fight epic interactive battles with everything from Orcs, Cyclops, Liches, Wyverns and much more. The gameplay of Dark Messiah is the best in the entire library of rpg's, and the game rewards creative fast paced combat with tons of ways of hilariously killing your enemies. The storyline is good scripted, good voice acting and multi choice ending. It's in many ways better than Oblivion, Dragon Age and Mass Effect. To me Dark Messiah represent the last of the great action games like Heretic, Hexen, Quake and Doom.

reviewText: This game got dumped on by a lot of critics when it came out, and not without reason. Magic is gimpy, and the most powerful tactic by far is kicking dudes into pointy things. However, the fact remains that no game has ever made first person melee combat feel so good or so smooth, not even zeno clash. It's also one of the few games that effectively combines action and stealth gameplay, so that both approaches seem worthwhile, even using both if you've spent your skillpoints appropriately. Just do yourself a favor and don't bother with hardcore mode. It makes all humanoid enemies and possibly spiders invincible unless you knock them down and hit them with a coup de grace, which makes combat incredible tedious.

voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Ok, before people start bashing this game for the admittedly terrible voice acting and lame plot, consider what this game does. It is an action RPG that focuses on being smarter and more skilled than the NPCs. Sure, you could charge at an enemy and beat them to death with your sword; OR, you could shoot them with your bow, crush them with collapsable scaffolding, drop them down a pit, down some stairs, hit them with barrels, kick them into spikes, burn them, kick them into each other, or stab them in the back. The level up system is kinda lackluster, and does seem like it takes forever to get some useful skills. If you RPG damage sponges want a game that doesn't require much thought to play, by all means, don't buy this game. If you are looking for an RPG that challenges you on multiple levels and prefer gameplay to plot and VAs, give this a shot. A good plot does not make a bad game better, but a bad story doesn't hinder a good game.

reviewText:
The M&M series is primarily either an old-school, pen-and-paper style dungeon crawler, or a card game. Meanwhile, Dark Messiah is an oddity; it's a first-person action RPG in the Source engine, of all things! Picture Half-Life 2 with swords and sorcery instead of guns and robots, and you'll have a good idea of what this game plays like. Going into this title, I did not expect much. I knew it was from Arkane Studios, the same folks who delivered the excellent Dishonored, but all the same I was not prepared to fall in love with the game.

The Story
Most certainly Dark Messiah's weakest aspect. You play as Sareth, an apprentice serving under the wizard Menelag. Your master has sent you to deliver some sort of artifact to a friend in a far off city, but has transported a woman into your conciousness to be your guide for mysterious reasons. Xana is pretty much a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ version of Cortana from Halo. You'll either tolerate her character, or outright despise her. Once you actually get to your destination, stuff hits the fan and you're thrust into a campaign to defeat an evil Necromancer. There are quite a few plot twists along the way. The biggest will probably be obvious to you, but I can guarantee there are plenty of left-field ones. The question is... will you even care enough to, well, care about what happens? 6/10

The Gameplay
Ahhh, now here's Dark Messiah's shining beacon of awesomeness. I'm going to be blunt about this one, straight out of the gate: Dark Messiah has the greatest first-person combat I've experienced in a game. The guys at Arkane are wizards when it comes to first-person animations; everything is incredibly silky smooth and satisfying to witness and interact with. As you progress through the game, you'll be rewarded Skill Points which you can then distribute as you please through two skill trees. There's no skill that will drastically change up how you play; just some generic More HP" or "Slightly Bigger Fireball". Still
date: it works. You can also get some skill points by finding certain secret objectives within the world.\n\nDark Messiah's level structure is not unlike Doom or Quake... Littered with clever secrets (Some I didn't find until my fifth or so playthrough!) filled with special loot like new armors and weapons. Using either a Sword & Shield
voteText: Bows
votesHelpful: you'll slice and dice and stab and smash and burn and freeze and electrocute your way through hordes of Mercenaries

column20: and you can even disarm by power-attacking while aiming at the hand. Daggers are lightning fast. They chop up foes before they can get a swing in

The Art and the Sound
If you've seen any sort of high fantasy movie
column39: you've seen everything in Dark Messiah before. There's nothing visually that is truly original or outstanding. Admittedly

column42: the sound is a fair bit better. The clang of metal against metal and swooshes of air as swords tear through it are top-notch and really bring a little extra bit of immersion. You'll probably get sick fast of the early Mercenary enemies who seem to always begin a fight with "Hey
column44:
but the later gruffness of Orcs and Goblins and the like feel a fair bit more threatening. 8/10

The Replayability
Between the many different styles of equipment available
column45: the extremely harsh skill point limit
column46: and the myriad of secrets to be found in every corner
column47: you'll definitely want to play this beast more than once. The average first playthrough will probably take 12-15 hours. There are multiple endings
column48:
but trust me; you won't be replaying just to see these. The addictiveness of the combat is far more a reason to do so than the plot. 9/10

In Summary
Dark Messiah came out in 2006

and found myself playing it over five times before getting bored. I legitimately count it among one of my favorite games now. Well worth the low price of admission these days!

reviewText: Dark Messiah of Might & Magic was surely ahead of its time when it was released, yet has left a profound imprint in the FPS genre, both for stunning graphical features and elaborate gameplay mechanics. A mixture of RPG elements and the instinctive and intuitive characteristics of a classic FPS title result in a stunning game with a rather compelling narrative, which is however secondary to the developers' intention of offering to the player an incredible amount of choices through the various scenarios, some of which are very inspired. Moreover, the multiplayer features a TF-like class structure with all the elements that make the singleplayer great and allows for hours of fun.

reviewText: Dark Messiah of Might & Magic was surely ahead of its time when it was released, yet has left a profound imprint in the FPS genre, both for stunning graphical features and elaborate gameplay mechanics. A mixture of RPG elements and the instinctive and intuitive characteristics of a classic FPS title result in a stunning game with a rather compelling narrative, which is however secondary to the developers' intention of offering to the player an incredible amount of choices through the various scenarios, some of which are very inspired. Moreover, the multiplayer features a TF-like class structure with all the elements that make the singleplayer great and allows for hours of fun.

reviewText: Old, but gold. The storyline is reminiscent of something your buddy obsessed with AD&D and not taking a shower would come up with, which isn't necessarily a bad thing. The combat, while simplistic, is gleefully frantic and satisfyingly visceral. There's just something great about getting your shield bashed out of your hand and having to kite a mob of five orcs around while trying to find the right moment to kick one of them into a bed of spikes. All in all, it's a relatively decent (and cheap) first-person arpg with a delightfully cheesy fantasy storyline and amazing combat to boot.

reviewText:
This is a first person action RPG with very enjoyable combat and well-designed levels. It may look a bit aged and the story is nothing to write home about, but it's still good fun.

You can make the protagonist Sareth a fighter, mage or rogue-type character, or a combination thereof. Depending on the skills selected, he will be able to use different equipment and/or spells. But for most of the game, the terrain and your right boot will be your most powerful weapons: kicking enemies into fires or spikes or off ledges is great fun and highly effective, as is getting them crushed by falling objects. While it might seem exploity, the environments are intentionally designed so you can decimate your enemies like this - and it still makes you feel like a clever ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ when you do. The occasional boss creatures are also pretty cool. Levels are long and very well made, with plenty of secrets to find,
The only real downside here is that the fast attacks in close combat feel a bit lacking in substance.

The story is basically your standard young apprentice ignorant of his shadowy origins embarks upon quest" type thing. It's not badly done but very predictable. What few narrative choices there are make next to no difference at all
date: choosing a different playstyle changes the game more.\n\nI cannot say anything about the multiplayer as I haven't played it
recommended: but I find the game to be worth getting regardless."

A bit late to this party but it is a fun game.
Take it for what it is thou.

You can go about to play the game in several different ways. Full melee, caster and sneaky or mix it up a bit.

There are issues with the game. The serious ones to me are the crashes(save a lot), overpowered weapons(frost bow 2 shot enemies if you freeze and then easy to headshot).

I do recommend it!

Have a jolly good day!

reviewText:
Very entertaining action game. What really makes this game stand out is the melee combat. I really liked how the attacks felt weighty and how attacking different body parts will do different damage and different effects towards your enemy, seeing your enemy get injured and hobble away and show that he is at low health was also lots of fun because a lot of games don't show you enemy opponents get injured by your attacks. Environmental kills were also really fun as you can kick your enemy off of cliffs, into fires, into spikes and traps etc, you can get really creative with how you deal with enemy encounters and watching the physics of the enemy's corpse as they fall down a cliff or some stairs is fun too, which is because it runs on the Source engine. There is many ways to mix your character's build with a mix of ranged, melee and magic attacks which adds replayabilty.

The designs of the world and characters is very nice, the game has a great high fantasy atmosphere that feels like real lived in world. Despite being an older game it has aged nicely in this regard.

There are multiple endings which offers replay value and adds weight to the story as it feels you can choose to be the good guy or the bad guy, which was interesting while the story itself was a bit cliched. The level design is quite linear and at parts could get a bit annoying with backtracking but the way you can build your character adds replayability to the fun combat that you'll want to play again, as you try different strategies. Overall an underrated game in the Might and Magic universe that really stands out due to its fun combat system and kicking things.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game is simply amazing. For an old game it has very nice graphics, interesting storyline and awesome gameplay. The combat system is really fun, especially with kicking. The game invites you to use the environment around you to your advantage, rather than just sticking to the usual combat methods. Plus it's always hilarious kicking enemies off the ledges and watch them fly XD! The other thing that is really awesome is the exploration element, there are some not-so-obvious places that you can get to find secret areas which most of the time contain very rewarding treasures.

All that being said, I really wish that the game was longer, I felt it was way too short and too linear, I think it definetly deserves more. Also there are a couple of annoying glitches that are not patched, they are not game-breaking but very annoying. I would like to try the multiplayer but there doesn't seem to be many that play the game anymore.

In the end, it's a very fun game and an awesome experience, I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
Great game. Awesome gameplay and great storyline.

You level up and can choose skills in which type of gameplay you want. You can use a bow for ranged combat, daggers for close and stealthy kills, a staff, or you could use the classic Sword and Shield. Or a 2 handed sword. Whatever you like, it's your skills to choose.

In the story there are some optional quests that you can complete. And you will also find yourself in places where you have to make a choice which changes the story (and not in a poor way).

Great game for a cheap price. 10/10

reviewText: If you can get it cheap, go and get this game. It's essentially an FPS/RPG hybrid in the vein of Deus Ex or STALKER. Though it's single-player only and clocks in about 12-15 hours of gameplay, there's a ton of replay value because of the many RPG options and arguably one of the best first person melee combat systems I've ever seen in a game. Disarm opponents, knock them off cliffs, light them on fire, throw objects to topple them, or just plain gutstab them and kick 'em in the face.

reviewText:
The game is based on Source engine so it makes it Half-Life 2 with magic and stuff.

If you spend your learning points right way you get lots of weapons — grenade launcher (Fireball spell), flamethrower (oh, I meant to say Inferno spell), the gravity gun (Telekinesis), and unlimited amount of first aid kits (Heal spell). Ammo (mana) regenerates slowly. Of course you can learn sword fighting or stealth instead and playing this way is much easier, but being mage is more fun. They also put in your head hot (literally) demon girl which works like Infolink from Deus Ex. You have to fight helicopters (dragons), armored vehicles (cyclops), combine soldiers (guards). There is even antlions level (spiders). If you are not comfortable with spiders, install No-Spider mod.

I feel like the game is a little bit underrated. It's interesting despite being absolutely linear. There is multiplayer mode but it doesn't function anymore.

Oh, and by the way, game adds French AZERTY keyboard layout into system settings. It looks like developers are not going to fix this bug, so don't forget to delete it after completing the game.

reviewText:
Dark Messiah of Might & Magic is a truly unique gem.

The variety in fighting approaches is outstanding and is supported and reinforced by the great and varied level design. What it lacks in the polish of a modern game it makes up for in old-school features like interesting level secrets and the encouragement of quicksave scumming.

As for the story, well, you shouldn't come to this game for the story but it's unique enough to live up to the Might and Magic license. The length of the single player campaign is alright though I can't help but feel that the demo has better pacing then the main campaign.

Also, the kicking is unparalleled.

Even without an active multiplayer scene, if you want interesting non-shooter action with a hint of RPG this is your best bet.

reviewText:
Actually it's a good game. It's based on sourse, but it's an first person RPG, Oblivion-like. And though it has a small skills tree, the game offers you a nice variety of tactical solutions for your battles, you can impale enemies on spikes, push them off the cliffs, cut ropes so stuff fall on their heads, throw random objects at them, stun them and finish them off later... There is plenty of options and I didn't even mentioned the half of them, also there is a grappling bow, so you may climb some difficult to reach places and a pretty decent variety of weapons of all kinds. There are couple of points I'd like to mention to you first:

1. Game is linear. You may choose your approach to the situation as you wish, but it's a straight-line story you'll follow.
2. Choose your class wisely. Warrior, assasin or mage... Though it would help to have some extra perks from other classes trees, points are given for completing parts of the main story, so I'd suggest to invest them in the build that suits your gamestyle the most.
3. Keep all the stuff you'll find. You never know when you could need it.
4. Secrets, puzzles, hidden loot, etc. Be observative.
5. Use your surrounding to your advantage, you won't always be able to win by brute force.

reviewText:
I remember way back when this game was about to be released. The entire gaming community online was going bonkers with this game, the demo that had been released roughly a year prior had been completely broken down.
It was hacked and people discovered loads and loads of hidden features and at that point unused enemies that had giant errors as skin. Everyone was waiting, including me,  and then at the day of release....Nothing, no one bought it, review sites gave Dark Messiah a horrible rating calling it less than average.
Me and a friend of mine were even the first people to buy it in our country, the game sales guy was shocked that we were the only 2.

And now, after so many years, it still recieves horrible reviews from critics, but I'll step up to defend it. LEt's just go over it point by point see where and how they are wrong.
This review will contain spoilers but I highly recommend it if you haven't played it yet.

First off, the Story.
-------------------

People say the story is transparent, why? Because the game is called Dark Messiah? Or how about that first cut scene, you know where you actually SEE the ending in a dream.
I never can understand why anyone would say that, the game never tries to fool you.
Others might say that there really isn't much story to begin with....which is also false.
Most of the story actually lies in the past, things that have come and gone already, I think it has enough depth.

Gameplay
-----------

I've heard more than enough times that the combat is repetitive, but I don't understand why.
This is where Dark Messiah excels , never not once in playing it have I gotten bored during combat, fighting enemies is never the same. On the highest difficulty setting fine you know, yes the enemies have some really cheap hits, that do a heck amount of damage. But I never saw it as unfair, only that I had to be better, faster, more cunning and slippery.
Everything is a weapon, going from a big Wooden Barrel, to a bucket of plain rocks.
Often I found myself actually reloading a certain fight scene when it went to EASY, killing 5 vampire knights without any damage....no that didn't do it for me, so I did it again and after 40 retries I finally succeeded again.

And the kick, nothing beats that, if there's a ledge someone is going down, and it never gets old.


RPG or Not?
-------------

I wouldn't call Dark Messiah an RPG, persé. Howeverit does have RPG elements. But you don't gain skill points for killing enemies, and there's no class system.
Most people really hate that about this game, but I don't. At least it's a refreshing take upon the genre, just build your own class. And if you don't have enough skills to finish your end goal...well you screwed up not the developers.

The only thing that I kinda don't like is the fact that in a way you are forced to have at least 1 magical ability.


Ending Good or Bad
---------------------

There's only one true ending, and that's the evil ending. The game is called Dark Messiah, the ending is shown to our protagonist in the beginning in some sort of vision. Even the crew of Might and Magic themselves kinda admitted to which was the real ending when they included good old Kha-Beleth in the series.

Again a refreshing take, not everything has to be sunshine and lollipops with rainbows.

Final score I give it a 10/10, play this, love this and enjoy this.

reviewText:
I remembered playing a short demo of this game years ago and bought it on a whim.  I was not disappointed.  There are a few excellent points in its favour:

1.  Excellent story and character progression with some great set-pieces.
2.  Well-made combat with enough environmental situationality to keep it constantly fresh (even though Normal is too easy and Hard is too difficult)
3.  Well, it's old, so reasonably cheap and definitely worth a try

Perfect for fans of Dishonoured; I realised they were made by the same people before I checked who made each.  A similar classic with a great story.  Well worth your time.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GKiyeAFkXcY&list=UUnQL0hzRCQwxnRMV9Nn9i6g
DMOMM is a good game, that just misses the mark of been great. Let me start with the story. You take the role of Sareth – an orphan who is train by the wizard Fenring. Years goes by and finally our hero is tasked to deliver a crystal to another wizard named Menelag in the city of Stonehelm. But before you leave master Fenring summon a woman name Xana, who will be your guardian and she settle in Sareths head. When you're getting closer to the city you see people leaving because army of Necromancers are about to attack. And they do and Sareth saves the city … for now. After the battle you meet Leana, niece of Menelag and the wizard himself. Sareth goes to sleep and in the middle of the night he is attacked and here start your adventure. The story is the big minus of the game – it is so predictable. The other thing is the stealth. There is no point of using it, which is a shame, but game is design  around to fight, not to sneaking.
There is some rpg in DMOM and it's not deep. You earn skill points by doing tasks and you distribute them in three categories. There isn't big skill tree and some people won't like it, I personally don't mind that much. It would be better if the developer put little more variety in the skills.

The combat is what I like most. It's is somewhat repetitive, but awesome. At your disposal they are swords, bows, staffs, daggers, shields, magic all their pluses and minuses. When clicking the left mouse button you perform normal weak attack, but if you hold it you execute power strike, which do more damage and depending of your movement the animation is different.

While battling the enemies adrenaline meter is filling. When it's full you can kill enemy with one hit and it is gory. Lets not forget the mighty kick. In a lot of cases enemies will stand near a cliff, fire, spikes and you give them the boot it's instant death.
The magic spell are nothing new or exiting. You can freeze, shoot fireballs, lightnings. The most useful spell for me is Charm. There is nothing more satisfying of making group of enemies killing each other.
The level design is great. You will walk in to caves, island full with ruins, sewers, castles. Exploration is rewarded, they are a lot of hidden stuff.
There is a decent variety of enemies, but their design is generic. You will encounter humans, orcs, dragons, goblins, zombies, spiders, cyclops and the most annoying enemy – ghouls. Most of them has some weakness, but not the ghouls. They are just annoying.
The game is hard. If you walk right in front of more than two-three enemies, most likely you will die. Use the weaknesses, set some explosive traps.
Despite some shortcomings DMOMM is good game and I definitely recommended it.

reviewText:
I don't quite know what it is about this game that keeps me coming back to it. (At least twice after my initial playthrough.) I know nothing about the Might & Magic world or the other games set in it. I'm sure there's more story the characters and events in this game. I hope so since the story felt a bit disjointed and incomplete. I was put in middle of events I have no idea why they happened. The characters were never properly introduced either. Or built upon.

But the gameplay. There is that little something in the gameplay. I can't quite put my finger on it but best I could describe it is solid. This feels and plays like a very solid game. What that means I'm not too sure. I have no problems with any of the gameplay mechanics. I just love how the gameplay feels.

The graphics, despite being an old game, still hold up just fine. It has that old time 3D feel but that's just fine. I think it adds to the game. It is also worth noting that this is a very linear game. There is very little exploration to do. And I dislike most linear games.

I really like this game. Every time I think about it I get the urge to try it out once more. The story isn't all that interesting to me and graphics just do their job. It's the combat and overall gameplay that keeps me coming back. But I just don't know why.

If this ever goes on sale again I definitely suggest picking it up, just don't expect a great story. Even so this is one of my favorite games among such popular hits as Trine 2, Mirror's Edge, and Psychonauts as you can see from my profile showcase. I feel like this is a very underrated and unknown game.

If you're a game designer or a wanting to be one I suggest you check out this game. Perhaps you could take apart and analyze why this gameplay feels so different from all the other sword and sorcery RPGs. I genuinely  think there is something to be studied here.

reviewText: An action-adventure taking place in a fantasy world and all this with Valve's Source engine! I liked how varied game they developed - you can be a master of swords or become an archer or simply stick with magic. There are a lot of traps here and there which means the game lets you use the environment to kill your opponents. For example: you kick a support beam after which a dozen barrels are dropped on your enemy. Or you can sneak up to those standing near cliffs and kick them down into the abyss. This environmental combat is what makes Dark Messiah a unique game. Looting exists but you cannot really equip that many weapons - it is as if the creators wanted to put the system there as it was a requirement for an RPG anyway.\n\nPutting the insignificant looting system aside Dark Messiah is a very good fantasy game. If you love Might & Magic you can pick up its FPS iteration: you won't regret it.

I currently just enjoy using the cheats, give myself full poweres and explore the different levels and how i can complete them.

This is a truly awsome game

reviewText: This game really deserves a sequel or spiritual successor. The first person sword fighting is good, satisfying and possibly the best of its kind (haven't played Dishonored yet). There are some issues with hit detection, and Flurries (your main attack, but you'll probably be using power strikes most of the time) is pretty crap, but apart from that the melee combat is done pretty well and has a good sense of impact and physicality, whether you're blocking a strike with your shield or kicking an enemy. The RPG elements, which let you use magic and stealth as well, and environmental weapons (wall spikes, fires, flimsy wooden supports that can be broken to topple barrels and crates on enemies etc.) allow for different approaches to each battle. The platforming is also decent.\nThe game isn't perfect of course. Some sections of the game don't cater well to a specific build, boss fights are dull and in some cases (usually when they fly) annoying, and some of the enemy types aren't nearly as fun to fight as others. There have also been complaints about the plot, characters and voice acting, but I wasn't bothered by them.\nBasically, if you're looking for good first person sword fighting and physics in a fantasy setting then Dark Messiah of Might and Magic is the game for you.

reviewText:
This game has the best combat system I've ever seen. You can use the enviroment to help you in combat. For example you can trigger traps, throw objects on your enemies, or kick them to water/from stairs, impale them on spikes, or climb above them and shoot them with your bow. As assassin you can hide in shadows and backstab your enemies. As wizzard, you can freeze your oponents, make them smaller or cast ice on earth and watch them as they slip on ice. You don't have to learn skills from one class, so you can learn anything and become anything you want. Some people say that it's useless to learn some skills, because the kicking is the most powerful weapon in game. It's not true. It's more effecient to be for example  assassin(and of course, it's more fun).
Game is linear, you cannot stray, but there are four different endings.You have been possessed by a demon which will help you and say funny comments on some situations in the game(and she's got sexy voice). The story is simple but good. The maps are very well designed. The atmosphere is different from location to location. Somewhere it's peaceful, elsewhere it's calm, or dark, or little disturbing.
The game is from 2006, but still good looking. Textures aren't high quality, but the illumination is perfect and enhance atmosphere. Music is mix of orechstral and industrial, someone can say it's dark fantasy.  You can find soundtrack on youtube. Sounds are average. Water sounds like water. The characters have very good voices, even the supporting characters. There are also ambient sounds. There are very good and further enhance the atmosphere.

Dark Messiah is the most underrated game I've ever played. It definitely should have second part. I played this game three times and it's still fun. There was still places that I didn't see in previous playthroughs.
Many people were dissapointed becasue they thought Dark Messiah is RPG. It's not. It's action game with RPG elements.

reviewText:
I'd give this game a 8/10:

It features a versatile combat system, where you can make extensive use of traps, physical objects squashing enemies and so forth. Futhermore, the story is told pretty well, but it references some Heroes of M&M V characters and events, making it possibly a little confusing in terms of who-is-who.
All in all, I found the game to be quite amazing.

So why only 8/10? Because of the bugs that still exist and that will likely never be fixed. I experienced nothing game-breaking, but it ranges from nuisances (i.e. the game crashes everytime I quit for me), over bothersome things (I had for instance some common shield in my inventory I could neither use nor drop, thus it just blocked one slot in the inventory), to real bugs (example: somewhere in chapter 9, you have to jump into water in a rather dark tower. For some reason world reflections caused the entire screen become white and the game was unplayably slow. I had to turn off reflections to see anything and to be able to play again).
Neither of those bugs is a real deal breaker, but the amount and versatility of them is truly annoying.

reviewText:
I have over 500 games in my Steam account, and the vast majority of them are still unplayed. So now I'm dedicating an hour to each of these games and writing a series of One Hour Reviews. An hour isn't very long to judge a game on, so think of this as more of a first impression, and take this review in the spirit in which it's given. Be sure to read other reviews from players who have spent more time in the game.

One Hour Reviews #38 - Dark Messiah of Might & Magic

I played a number of the very early Might & Magic Games.  In particular I remember playing a ton of Might & Magic VI.  I remember it as a role playing game before the Heroes of Might and Magic series overshadowed it with a completely different type of gameplay and focus on strategy.

Dark Messiah of Might and Magic is a different beast altogether.  It's not a turn based strategy game like Heroes is.  But it's also not an RPG like the original games either.  This is more of an action RPG, with an emphasis on the action.    You do have some RPG aspects, for example the game provides 3 skills trees, one for melee, one for magic, and a third for other skills.  The early skills are cheap, so it's easy to dabble in each of the skill trees.  I found this to be good because I was primarily focusing on melee, but early on I found it extremely helpful to train a heal spell.  I noticed I wasn't really healing on my own, but I would slowly get mana back, so being able to trade mana for health made things a lot easier.

Even with the skill tress and RPG elements, I still consider this game pretty RPG-lite.  If you are looking for an open-world type game, this isn't for you.  The story is linear and really the game feels more like an adventure game with an emphasis on combat than a typical RPG.  This may sound like a turnoff, but the combat is actually a lot of fun.  I really liked the feel of combat.  It isn't just smashing buttons or turning on auto-attack.

Another nice aspect to this game is the interactivity with the environment.  The game encourages you to kick the crap out of your enemies, either into a fire, or into a convieniently placed spike rack, or over the edge of a railing.  In fact arguably your foot is the best weapon in the game, at least from what I saw.

Probably the most fun I had in my hour of play involved a chandelier.  I cut a rope which caused this chandelier to start swinging around.  Meanwhile I had about 4 guards chasing me.  I'd run past the chandelier while it was on it's upswing, and the guards would stupidly follow me without paying attention and get smacked as the chandelier came back down.  It was kind of ridiculous as I'd watch the guards body ragdoll it's way across the room as if it was hit by a wrecking ball.  After about 3 laps around the room, I had killed all of the guards by chandelier.

My only complaint about the game was it was rather crash prone.  It crashed 3 times on me in the hour I played.  Once it crashed on startup, once it crashed as I was quitting the game, and once it crashed in the middle of the game.   Perhaps this is from me running Windows 10 (the game came out for Windows XP).  Looking at other reviews, this doesn't seem to be a common issue, so it may just be something specific with my setup.

Overall, the combat alone is enough to make this game fun, and to earn my recommendation.  I did not check out the multiplayer version of this, so my entire review is only based on the single player game.

reviewText:
A forced union of two personages from opposing factions gives birth to an unlikely hero.

Parents separated, mother dead, raised by foster family, apprenticed into the basics of wizardry. You are tasked to deliver a mysterious artifact to a guy who then dies, like, a few hours later. His hot niece, who totally has a crush on you, helps you retrieve the artifact from the bad guys. She dies. Or she doesn't. Anyway, in order to get even, and fulfill your destiny, you must find and use a skull. And then you die, but not really. Because your conscience, which also totally digs you, brings you back to life and triggers your mega-evolution. You can continue on the pokemon path, or choose to cleanse yourself of the annoying voices in your head, and then you get some hot lewt good vs undead. You kill some more guys, and then another guy, and then you can choose to either watch a cutscene, or the other one.

But srsly, I recommend it with all my limbs. If you haven't tried it before, you will notice similarities with Arkane's previous first-person slasher, Arx Fatalis. But with more emphasis on melee&ranged, and a simplified magic system. It features some damn awesome melee combat. Slashing, backstabbing, kicking, is just too damn fun. Also connects with the HoMM series (5th), but I won't say how because spoilers.

I give it a 9.75/10, but only because it makes me want to backstab people while walking down the street. Can't have that, man

reviewText: The only reason I powered through the god-awful writing, shallow voice acting, and generic and little-developed Lore was because of the fairly entertaining Gameplay, thanks to the game's use of the Source Engine. There is a leveling system which gives this First-Person Adventure Game permission to call itself an RPG, although it is rather flawed. Many Skills are only obtainable if all of the little experience you get throughout the game is poured into one Skill-Tree. Some of the most useful skills weapons or skilled are only possibly made available just before the game's Epilogue
date: which isn't actually an Epilogue but just the last chapter of the hollow story this game tells.\n\nI would recommend this game, but with a message of caution: What the game lacks in depth of Story and writing/acting, it (just barely) makes up for in fun, occasionally challenging Gameplay. While Dark Messiah provided me with around 75 hours of gameplay, it also gave me a terrible ending, in which none of your choices mattered. I was not surprised, but I was left with an empty feeling.

reviewText:
Dear Reader,

Simply put, this game was fun.

There are some frustrating issues with modern OS's and Dark Messiah crashing fairly often, but they aren't game breaking.
The story is a bit hokey, but it was still rather thrilling. The characters are a tad cliched, but a few still stood out.
The game has aged fairly well. The melee combat is still engrossing, and the environments are for the most part well made.

If you can find the game on sale, I would say it certainly it worth the playthrough. There is a multiplayer component, but that has remained untouched. I may update this review in the future if I happen to play it.

A demo is available, which would easilly allow you to try it out. There's no reason not to!

reviewText:
This game, in my opinion rocks. It's a splendid first-person adaptation with a very action-oriented control set. There is a delightful variety in abilityes/skills/spells, for the type of game anyway, and a goot spattering of secrets. The story isn't particularly incredible, but the game has aged fairly well considering its time!

You can use a variety of weapons, stealth, freeze enemies, kick them into spikes/over edges/underneath breakable roofs, etc.

It carries the M&M moniker but it's really more of a first-person run around and beat 'em up, contained within the M&M mythos, of sorts. Think more like the older Crusaders of type game and whatnot. Definitely would recommend it!

reviewText:
- Action-RPG.

Pros:
- Timeless classic.
- Fantastic combat mechanics, hardly reviled by any other game.
- Creative usage of environment (note: to kill your enemies in 1000 and 1 ways).
- Immense replay value: four classes, warrior, assassin/thief/bowman, mage/cleric/wizzard, four endings.
- Deep immersion. (Yes, you got a body in this game, too.)

Cons:
- Yes, there are bugs. And crashes.
- Balance is not optimal: what items you find and where, strength of classes".

- One of the best games ever made.
Period."

reviewText:
- Melee combat is amazing and satisfying
- Spells are mundane
- Stealth is less satisfying than full melee
(Stealth can actually be really hard since some parts require full balls deep yolo-mode and your damage/armor is low)
- Archery is... archery (meh)
- Story is a bit corny and weird
- You can't bang any of the hot grills
- Suffers from some frequent crashes (but only on loading screens and exiting)
- You're fighting a lot of the same monsters:
Ghouls, spiders, orcs, thieves, casters, vampire knights, a few liches, oh and 4x cyclops. There is enough to not make it boring, but after 30 spiders you'll start to notice it.
- Game suffers from some bugs, especially with the rope bow

Overall 6/10

I recommend it only if you can look past the flaws, because the melee combat combined with the traps and kicking is 10/10 fun guaranteed.

reviewText: Dark Messiah (which, if I'm right, has basically nothing to do with Might and Magic) is a pretty wierd game. It's basically a first person shooter, except medieval, so they had to do a lot of work on making melee combat interesting. They largely succeeded, honestly. It is totally fun to kick dudes around and into spikes and off cliffs, and the first-person movement and combat all looks and feels really good. It was an early Steam game, though, and people didn't like Steam, and there were issues with the multiplayer, and the voice acting and the plot are TERRIBLE, though, so it's sorta been forgotten. I think it doesn't deserve that at all. 4/5

reviewText:
At the right price, it's an OK buy.

Combat is too easy in the beginning, but too wacky in the end.  For example, staffs are great at the beginning, but they require magic affinity later on.  Eventually, they're awful since enemies move way too fast (such as ghouls and vampire knights), so those magic affinity points are wasted.  You don't really need them even for casting spells since mana potions recover mana at a fixed 50 mp/potion.  Daggers are the weapon of choice later on, but early on, you really can't assassinate everyone, especially when playing on hardcore.  Going stealth really doesn't yield many combat options aside from equipping stronger daggers and armor, but later on, you don't care anyway since you're just slashing like crazy to land hits on those fast enemies anyway.

Archery's mad weak.  Don't even bother going for headshots.  They don't count.

Magic is only good in the mid game.  In the beginning, spells are too weak.  In the end, they're strong, but only against individual enemies which means it doesn't help against packs (until you unlock inferno and sanctuary which are way OP, but only if you land the initial hit.  If you miss, then you might as well just reload your quicksave since you'll be dead before you know it).

The story's kind of interesting.  It makes you really think about good and evil since the plot isn't straightforward.  Good guy orcs that fight against not so bad demons is a neat angle, and in between is a powerhungry necromancer leader who's trying to stop a prophecy from coming true.  You can really think about why you're doing what you're doing.  The story never really explains why your father is locked away by dragons either, and it makes you wonder if his demonic" heritage is only opposed based on what he looks like.  There's no real indication that the demons did anything "bad" to deserve getting locked away.

Also

reviewText:
KICK EVERYTHING!  Kick them off cliffs. Kick them into spikes.  Kick barrels into enemies.  Kick shrine offerings into the pit.  Kick that annoying nagging NPC into demon-hell for the True Ending.

Be prepared to enjoy unique, open level designs with plenty of hidden areas.  First person combat mechanics that mix spells, range weapons, and melee all together.  And it works.  This is the combat you wish Skyrim had.  Some stealth is also possible although you cannot bypass most fights.  Instead use it to gain the initiative and pick the encounter location.

The story is decent too, with four possible endings and some real choices to make.  It's unfortunate more games have not emulated Dark Messiah.

reviewText:
Posted elsewhere in 2010, since I revisited this game recently, I feel the need to post this here.

Dark Messiah could have been an excellent (though still extremely linear) game. For one, the game's combat is probably one of the best uses of melee combat in a FPS, with excellent hit detection (but still not perfect) and combat that puts lots of importance in good use of the environment. It works for a bit, but then after a while something simply feels off and it does get boring if this isn't the first game you have ever played.

The game gives the illusion of having varied way of playing through it. The warrior, mage, and assassin archetypes are all present with the addition of archery. Now these classes" aren't static in anyway as you don't pick who you want to be at the start of the game. Instead you are awarded character points for completing objectives with which you are able to allocate to three different character traits: combat

reviewText:
I only thumb this down for one big reason but before we poke at that, lets look at the good stuff.
Pros -
1. This game runs on the source engine so it has that Half Life feel and sound face into it, making for a very nostalgic piece.
Along with that, the game is very fast paced and has a good, even difficulty with plenty of enemys in it.
2. The Story while now adays is a bit easy to catch on to still has a good number of twists and confusing ends for you to try and figure out on the quest.
3. The Combat is strong and the branching trees and inventory are easy to play with. Overall it takes no effort to getting used to the controls, only getting used to the task bar really.
With all these pros whats the one big issue with this game?
Cons -
It barely ever works. Reports from other players say they can barely get past the prologue, infact, the most infamous bug (the one I'm having) is that apparently, this old game from a generation ago will constantly crash on the major area of the game over and over and over. This ruins the entire experience as you'll be busy slashing at orcs while Leana is healing you, your about to land that killing blow! Then a black screen appears, the game says MM.exe is not working and all your blood lust is turned into rage. This is such a horrible flaw because its on every computer past Windows 8.1. That is total crap, the fact that an old game can't run on these high tech systems is like saying you can't use a bullet for your new fancy gun because it now needs Special Bullets". Until I find a fix for this
date: steer clear of this game unless you are below Windows 8.1."

reviewText:
Dark Messiah is a fantasy action game dressed up like an RPG.  As the nameless one you will explore castles, crypts, caves, orc villages and more on your quest to...I am not sure what the quest is but there is plenty to do/kill along the way.  However you better love the combat (melee, archery, magic) and scenery because the RPG aspects are bland and minimal.  There is character building but it is simple and never really changes how you play the game, just makes you stronger in your particular discipline or allows you to equip special weapons.  Also the skill points to “level up” are only available by completing quests, and there is a set amount so it takes forever to build your character and you are very limited in how strong you can get.  There is inventory management, but no stores to buy and sell, and what you find is also very limited.  Want to interact with NPC characters, there is none of that either except as scripted cut scenes.  As an RPG Dark Messiah is a failure, but as an action game it’s decent but very repetitive.  I made it over half way through hoping the game would get deeper or the story more interesting, but this really is just an action game at heart, and a fairly generic shallow one at that.  If that’s what you are looking for Dark Messiah is not a bad game, however if you are looking for an RPG as I was look elsewhere.

I played with the Steam Gamepad, with a little tweaking it worked well and you can map everything you need to the controller if you are so inclined.
voteText: 7 of 21 people (33%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game. For the part of the game that I was able to play, I did enjoy it a lot. It's a high fantasy first-person linear RPG, with different skill trees, combat types, and hidden secrets. By linear I mean you progress from one level to the next and can't return to older areas. It works really well - the game is surprisingly fun when it works.

UInfortunately, I ran into numerous bugs that made it very difficult to proceed. One bug about 2-3 hours into the game makes it unplayable - no matter what you do at a certain stage, you are guaranteed to lose if this bug crops up. Restarting the entire level doesn't fix it. The only way to avoid the bug is to completely restart the entire game, and hope that you don't get the bug AGAIN, which would require another restart.

I've searched for patches and mods to fix this and there are none. Until this game-breaking bug gets fixed, I cannot recommend this title, as much as I wish to enjoy it.

reviewText: At first, the game seems rather well made. However, as you progress, you realize just how horrible it actually is. Several fights are outright impossible if you are building a ranged fighter instead of a melee fighter, many other areas you'll go through your entire mana pool just to down one regular enemy. Arrows are slightly better, except that you can't really fire them at a fast enemy closing in on you, and you can't block with a bow.\n\nRepeatedly, the game has decided I died even though I still had over 20 HP left after being hit, the orc boss decided to smash my face in during the cutscene while he was talking without giving a chance to fight back(twice), and that's just two of the bugs I have encountered playing this game. Honestly I'd probably be rather ♥♥♥♥♥♥ if I hadn't gotten it essentially for free. Don't waste your money on this game.

reviewText:
I got hyped about this game reading reviews. After playing for more than half of the game, I honestly regret buying it, even in 75% discount price. This game might have been great in 2006, but it's annoying in 2015 and not really fun. I could overlook the technical aspects due to game's age (except for the forced motion sickness mode), but even the gameplay mechanics are poor compared to newer games (or even, say, Half Life 1).

The gameplay issues
Enemy variety is tragic. There are like 4 different enemy types, everyone looks the same, and an area is usually populated by a single type or two. You fight them over and over again.
The fact that you can use environment to kill is cool, but in this game you are forced to do so, and you're almost forbidden to use standard means (like, a sword!). Because the enemies are extremely hard when fighting the standard style (they can parry as fast as you can strike and they never miss a parry), but they are extremely vulnerable when anything hits them. Throwing a jar at them can yield a better result than hitting them with a sword from behind to a neck (really, because a jar or a barrel knocks them down and you can then kill them instantly, but hitting them from behind to a head doesn't... makes real sense, and definitely not a gimmick!). So using environment is not a great addition to your fighting style here, it's shoved down your throat and you need to use it all the time.

The technical issues
The game is full of bugs that either make you fail instantly or prevent completion of the area. I had to load a past save several times to work around those. Make sure you save (and don't rely just on a quicksave).
You'll get stuck on anything and everything. Using ladders, ropes, jumping through a window, all of that is incredible pain and you'll often die because the engine is dumb.
The lighting is so bad that half of the game is well lit and the other half is pitch black (like house interior during a day). Enabling HDR makes it even worse. You can't see a damn thing and you need to use night vision a lot just to work around poor lighting. Adjusting gamma doesn't help too much, you'll still see sh** and the rest will be blinding bright.
The hitboxes and targeting, oh damn. Very often you hit something completely else, like a wall *behind* a person. Performing an execution is a random chance whether the game considers you in the right place or not.
The UI for switching weapons is far from usable. You can switch from sword+shield to a bow, but you can't switch back. You can either switch bow->sword (and only then add a shield), or switch bow->shield+random weapon (usually not the one you want). Very clever.
Forced motion sickness. Oh yes, you human weaklings, the developers will let you suffer, you deserve it. You can disable head bobbing, but that's the least of the problem. The image tilts every time you strafe. Every time you move sideways, your view moves unnaturally, right side up left side down, or vice versa, like boat swaying on a see. I found a way to disable it, otherwise I'd have refunded this immediately. You can see my solution on pcgamingwiki[pcgamingwiki.com].

I ended in chapter 6 in crypts, fighting zombies. I didn't see sh**, everything was pitch black so I had to constantly toggle night vision, and it was near impossible to execute a zombie, because of targeting glitches, so the fights took eternity. There was no fun in that.

How long can you enjoy throwing barrels at people and kicking them from ramps, when you're forced to do that a thousand times over and there's no other way? 9 hours seems to be my experience. (In hindsight, I was really persistent.)

reviewText:
This game is actually a game of football. EA Sports actually has the rights to the sequel, and has lent the same code for fifa road to world cup (tm) so that they would use the same mechanics, only instead of a leather ball it's orcs, spiders, humans that you kick around.
And they fly! Look at them fly! Like tiny dragon butterflies they fly and fall of walls, on spikes very accurately placed so that you can kick your foes into (it's a soccer goal, I know).
The magic system is awesome: You have to wait for many seconds in between spells, that are not really better than melée combat at any time in the game. Also, the enemies can run forever, and you can, which is very good, because that means you actually get to die, when 45 enemies spam over you and can run forever while you are like a fat, retired Ronaldo that is about to be hacked to death by angry orc mobs.
Also, ingenious, is the fact that the animations are not skippable in game. I love that. You can't stop the orc cleric from having the most boring speech ever.
The stealth system is mandatory, and even if it doesn't work, exactly as in real life, it might bring you some advantage before you kick the enemies and you see them flying in the air.
Fighting is amazing; your hits don't land, you have no clue how much damage you're dealing, and that makes the game far much more real. Also, using first person shooters with movement combos for power strikes is ingenious, i.e. you will break many mouses. Mouses are fun to break. And Overrated.
The game is also very smart: In order to increase the user experience, it will have mandatory game stops that happen at random. Yes, the game will crash on many animations, which makes for excelent user experience and will leave you hungry for more.
Don't buy this game.

reviewText:
Clunky, dated combat, terrible design choices (forcing a stealth or mage character into 1v1 melee combat with an enemy that's pretty much guaranteed to oneshot them on higher difficulties? no thanks), and it's on the original Source engine which has aged as gracefully as Iggy Pop.

It's still fun though, if you're a pure melee build who just carries a bow for cheesing certain large enemies, and the visuals hold up well enough after 9 and a half years. Story's not bad, either.

Protip: Bind mouse 1 to kick to instantly win.

Wait for a sale, otherwise pass on it.

reviewText:
A girl I met nearly half a decade ago who really liked this game. She liked it so much she actually bought me a copy to play with her, but while I was downloading it (lengthy process back then)  she called me and told me that she tested positive for Hep-C and that I should get tested. At this point I couldn't bare to play video games so I left it unplayed. After A few weeks of not really speaking to her I finally get my results back, and that's when my life changed for the worse forever. Results came back positive. After this point I never could bear to ever play it. Sometimes when I see it in my libary I cry uncontrolably at the mistake I made.

This game will break your heart and destroy your liver with an incurable disease.
0/10

reviewText: I was pretty excited to play this game, as it looked like the sort of thing that I would enjoy. However, whenever I try and get past the main menu, the game proceeds to crash. After many hours of trying various fixes and searching the internet, I found that this is quite a common problem that has STILL not been addressed by the developer, making the game unplayable for many. Since so many people have the same issue as me, I am confident this is not a 'user error' and I have had no problems playing other games using the Source engine. The fault appears to be with Arkane Studios and until this issue is rectified, it appears that many people have had their money taken for a broken product and therefore I cannot recommend buying this game currently.

reviewText:
At first I found this game rather enjoyable. It introduces alot of very interesting and unique concepts along the way, and item progression, as well as skill progression, actually matter quite a bit in this game. The main pitfalls (heh...) of this title are the mechanics, the physics engine. Enemies are tough to kill in combat, even if you tool yourself out with the best equipment possible, the game is brutally difficult. As such, many just resort to ranged combat, and trick the AI into getting stuck, so they can peg them with dozens of arrows.

Main issues I encountered were such:

Getting lost again and again, which I realised was partly due to several progression bugs which prevent key doors from opening. The level layout does tend to make everything sort of blend in, so figuring out just which corridor contains the identical looking wooden door you need to go through does happen.

The rope bow/arrow, well before the latest Croft game and other titles empoyed it, is quite fun, until you start floating through walls while climbing ropes, because the physics engine was not programmed to deal with this vital game mechanic. The number of times I died whilst trying to do the fiddliest of tricky platforming (which as always, in a first person game, is just an awful idea from the start), due to the rope intersecting with a chunk of rock, which caused me to noclip out of the level... It gets frustrating very quickly.

Finally, the magic in this game feels utterly flat. Fireballs hit enemies as though you just threw a small water balloon at them. Lightning appears to have the same effect as assaulting your enemy with a particularly wet piece of paper. There was absolutely no appeal to using magic in this game except as a means to use the mana I have anyway.

If you really want to try it, nothing I say is going to stop you, but otherwise i'd say leave this game where it belongs, in the past.
