reviewText:
Originally posted on July 11, 2009

Dark Messiah of Might and magic is a truly disappointing game. From the clunky controls to the frustratingly simple combat, the core game mechanics are boring, and the presentation is quite shabby to boot.

Graphics- While some of the game's graphics can look pretty good, the overall effects are very uneven. Especially the game's more open areas look absolutely atrocious in comparison to other source games, as low res textures and bad backdrops abound.

Sound- I found the sound design to be generic and not really anything special, although it did the job. The voice acting was pretty bad.

Gameplay- The hack and slash mechanics with magic mixed in work much better in other titles that mix these dynamics, but for some reason Dark Messiah features a terribly frustrating control scheme and nonsensical combat mechanics that often feature your character taking damage full seconds after the enemy blows have been deflected. Button mashing combined with circle strafing led me to the most success when playing this game. In short, the gameplay, enemy, weapon and skill systems are pretty generic and do not provide for a satisfying experience.


In addition to these concerns, the story is very very dull, providing no narrative flow or any kind of imperative to your actions.

Overall, I'd say Dark Messiah is a sad example of low-budget game development gone wrong.
voteText: 6 of 52 people (12%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game is a combination of an action game with some RPG and magic elements. It seems to be very, very interesting.

BUT.

Could this game be any more harder? It's so hard it's almost ridiculous. I never was able to even finish the first level, even on Easy difficulty. Already the first enemies you encounter are like boss battles. I mean, even with bow and arrow an enemy takes about 5 to 10 shots before dying. A sneaky shot from behind to the head from behind doesn't deal any more damage.

This is ridiculous.

Additional to that comes the somewhat extremely clunky, not responsive controls. It's just plain awful and frustrating to play.

The levels are designed to provide unique ways to kill an enemy, like kicking them into spikes / over the railing or destroying some planks which hold some barrels. This seems to be the ONLY way to succeed in this game, since a direct confrontation is pure suicide. Further problem is: Moving your character seems to be too stiff and not responsive and the back-steps are so tiny you're constantly being attacked.

In conclusion for me, this game is way too hard, clunky and therefore no fun at all. I really tried it on Easy difficulty several times with different approaches and even on this setting its unplayable. For hardcore gamers or those who get the right tactic this might be a challenge but for gamers who just want some casual fun now and then, not a good choice.

Update: Curiosity made me cheat - so I activated the God Mode, gave myself about 300 skill points and put everything to the maximum. I have to say: Good thing I didn't play this game the normal way so the disappointment came rather short. The visual effects and presentation of the spells like fireball or lightning bolt (both are fired through your hands) are looking, feeling and sounding very, VERY uninspired and boring.

Don't buy it. And for the haters: Just respect another person's opinion. It's not that hard ;)

reviewText: A fun, if familiar first person magic/melee game with light RPG elements. Runs on the Source engine so don't expect the prettiest game but it runs like a a dream. Large, nicely designed levels with lots of secrets to find. A number of ways to play through the game whether you want to go magic, melee or archer. Special shoutout to the greatest kick in the history of gaming. Kicking enemies off of ledges or into the ocean is a blast. The story is slight but there are four different endings depending on a few decisions. I think I got this game for $5 in a Might and Magic pack so I'd say it's definitely worth that.

reviewText:
Wow. My first playthrough... This is a missed Action/RPG gem for sure.

The combat is SO much fun. There are so many options to use...
Range attacks, magic (and different kinds of magic - Fire trap. *BOOM!*), melee, use the environment, KICK, kick and use the environment...Each with different strengths, weaknesses and advantages.

The characters are amusing.  Having the seductive 'succubus' voice of Xana in your head all the time provides tons of interesting dialogue.

There is the occasional awkward collision issue... but there are often minor and having blocked progress yet. I'm about four chapters in and I'm quite impressed.

The graphics look a little dated but are holding up quite well IMHO.

Certainly recommended.

reviewText: This is a pretty interesting game. It's built on Source, and looks pretty good for the time. The mechanics are introduced in a fashion that doesn't leave you with many questions and the gameplay is pretty solid. There's a basic RPG framework built into the game that allows you to choose specialisation in three different primary areas of mastery. Stealth, Magic, and Weaponmastery. The enemy variety is mixed up enough to keep you from getting too bored, but the formula is pretty much the same for most humanoid enemies. The game includes a kick that has the ability to knock back a lot of enemies, and the game liberally places hazards for you to take advantage of, so most often it's a lot easier for you to just kick someone off of a ledge or into spikes than actually fight them.\nI feel the game is geniunely very difficult without taking the heal spell from the mage tree, but other than that, you can play the game without there being too many necessary skills. I would say that it's mandatory to either get magic or bows, however.

reviewText:
A severely underrated game.  I've played through it multiple times, and will probably continue doing so.

Completely different than all the other M&M games and much more intimate, IMO.
The combat is perfect.  You're given the option of using multiple types of weapons from swords, daggers, staffs and more. Each with their own special traits.  Nothing feels the same.  Wielding magic in this game is awesome.
Stealth is also close to being on par with the original Thief games.

This game, even being almost 9 years old, is still better than 90% of the other First Person RPG's.  It still stands the test of time with great storytellind and rewarding gameplay. I think it even has better combat and story than Skyrim.  But it isn't open world like Skyrim is.  I keep hoping/wishing M&M would sequal this game, or keep progressing with this genre in some other way.  I think it does much better then their current stock of games.

To the point - Get this game. its a 10/10

reviewText:
Seriously underated game.

Great combat and gameplay. Combat starts with simple hack and slash movements, but gets more advance as you earn skill points and spend them. Best first person melee combat I've seen, and this game is nearly 10 years old, and no one have gotten close to this level of fun first person melee.

The story is fun, and gives a few interesting morallity choises along the way, leading to diffrent endings.

While the game runs on the Source(HL2 and others) engine, its kinda disapointing the Source games modding community never picked up on this game. But I guess the lack of modding tools kinda didn't help on that area. This game had so much potential.

At its low price, its worth a try.
Hours of fun, and some good replayability. I still pull out this game from time to time to try things diffrently.

reviewText:
Arkane Studios never was a well-known studio until their deal with Bethesda to make the critically acclaimed game; Dishonored. Before their rise to recognition. Arkane Studios made a semi-obscure game called Dark Messiah of Might & Magic.

Dark Messiah of Might & Magic, is the story about a young man named Sareth who has been trained his whole life by his mentor named Wizard Phenrig. In time he is finally given a task on helping his mentor Phenrig to find a sacred crystal called the Shantiri Crystal. After retrieving the Crystal, he's sent off by Phenrig to travel to the city of Stonehelm in which he's to deliver the crystal to another Wizard named Menelag, who is lord of Stonehelm. Though Sareth doesn't go alone and is given a spirit guide by Phenrig called Xana, who resides in Sareth mind.

DMOMAM (Dark Messiah of Might & Magic) story is possibly one of the worst stories a fantasy game could ever have. From the characters names, dialogue and boring and forgetful lore. DMOMAM doesn't seem to have any redeeming qualities in this field. Characters are usually shuffled in and out as quick as possible with very little backstory or personality to them. Many of the characters are more annoying than interesting. The spiritual guide; Xana is by far the most annoying out of the bunch as she literally talks in a sinister and almost hammy voice which is off putting beyond belief. The voice acting in the game is also terrible with chew-scenery attitudes and almost wooden performance from each character. Even if they were good it wouldn't have saved the goofy dialogue.

Though this may be the case for DMOMAM, what the game really shines on is its gameplay. DMOMAM's gameplay features a wide range of skills and traits for Sareth to choose from. This game is more fantasy RPG in skills than any other aspect. The game provides Stealth, Combat and magic as the main skills in which you can choose from. When specializing in one skill it can be very satisfying taking out enemies, like using a fireball to sizzle opponents alive, hack off a enemies head with sword, use the bow to take out targets from a distance and use Stealth to backstab your enemies silently. All is great fun and having the use of the kick mechanic can send enemies flying to their death onto spiked walls or off ledges. This is helped by the fact that the game engine that they use is the Source Engine. Which does good use with the physics and certain traps that are featured in the game.

DMOMAM does have some slip-ups with the combat though, sometimes the games hit detection glitches up, making you miss your opponents body, leaving you open to be hit. Because the game uses an actual character in first-person than a set of floating hands, it can be hard to navigate when climbing up stones and buildings in high places, leading you to a quick death. The stealth though good in some areas, is flawed in that it’s too easy to sneak and hide. The game uses an indicator which goes from 0-4 bars (0 being exposed, 4 being hidden), sometimes you'll be completely hidden even though you are out in board daylight which doesn't make any sense.

The graphics in the game are quite good and have aged well since the games release, with good physics and great lighting and textures, the game does holds up very well and helps with the immersion of the game. Art design of the world is quite boring when located in cities such as Stonehelm but at great when going through the mountains and dark caves. The sound design is quite weak when coming to certain sound especially from magic spells.

DMOMAM though is a game with tons of potential but a lot of things bring it down. It is a fun game though and will keep you entertained due to its RPG skills tree which will give you a decent amount of replay value.

(Strong) 6.50/ 10.0

reviewText: NOT always easy to set up on any OS other than Windows XP (not impossible, but they made a few odd design choices that Vista and 7 don't like much), this is a fantastic game. One of the first to use the Source engine, you step into the role of a wizard's apprentice and go treking through your round-of-the-mill fantasy setting. Conspiracies and such follow, but suffice to say that the game's emphasis on physics and a realistic first-person perspective (you ride into town in a wagon, which makes for a really nice intro) more than make up for its short-comings. I learned that the third or forth time I impaled a grunt on a spike by kicking him off of the roof, only after first ramming his head into the roof itself several times. Violent, oh yes, but plenty fun.

reviewText:
Preliminary Review
As I've only put in one 3 hour session of this game, this is simply a preliminary review of my experience so far.

Pros:
- Mechanics: The game mechanics are quite interesting. Some might say 'ahead of it's time' others might say 'just plain wierd.' It isn't like a traditional RPG in a lot of ways, with no clear stats to manage. But there is gear and skills to choose from, and different ways to approach the games problems. All of those are quite solid, although the game doesn't do a very good job of telegraphing any of it, or explaining it. The underlying cake, while a bit old, is still reasonably tasty.
- Atmosphere: While visually dated, the tone of the game is fairly robust, with consistent motifs playing through with nods to old Might and Magic storylines. What this boils down to is the cream of the cake, which while basic, is still ok.

Cons:
- Graphics: Visually the game has not aged well. Compared to Half-Life 2 which also used the Source Engine, DM looks craptacular.

- Difficulty curve: The game throws you to the wolves quite quickly. Given the ways that the combat, stealth and magic are unusual, this learning curve can be quite sharp as not only is the player having to learn new systems for a game, they have to learn new systems FOR THE GENRE. Comparisons abound between DM and Skyrim, and while they are significantly different, what has made Skyrim remarkably successful is it's approachability - something that DM clearly lacks. On the flipside, the combat and mechanics as mentioned above do allow for a deeper experience than Skyrim, but it does require more work from the players part in order to get the full enjoyment from that experience.

Summary

If you're looking for a something quite different, and don't mind picking up something that is a little dated, give Dark Messiah a go.

reviewText:
This is a quite underatted game. It has the basic RPG theme of weapons and magic and arrows and etc. but what i find so unique about it, is it's combat system. It's very, dynamic. Very, very dynamic. Fighting is very enjoyable with a selection of different types of weapons with the same style base, with little intresting tweaks to how your charecter attacks. Also you have a Duke Mighty Foot attack, which is really enjoyable.

I actually enjoyed this a bit more than skyrim, because in games like skyrim, its click constantly and seeing the same attack movment, here it's about swinging in certain directions and blocking at certain times and feels like your actually having a DYNAMIC sword fight.

Dynamic is really the word i normally use to describe this, because everything about it is so dynamic and free flowing.

At least give the demo ago and try it out, its really enjoyable.

*also dont trust the console versions. At all.*

reviewText:
This a great first person sword fighting type of game that uses the source engine and has a medieval background. It is very good and comparable to oblivion. It is more graphic though with some small nudity and some gore.
The graphics are quite great and what makes this game diferent then other similar games is the fact that pretty much anything can be a weapon. You can kick people off cliffs you can throw barrels at your enemies you light people on fire and impale them on spikes.
This game says might and magic but has little to no relation to the Heroes or might and magic series.
This game is a bit like half-life meaning that you are the pretty much silent antagonist that goes through a linear game following peoples orders to the end. The best thing though is you are destined to be good or evil and you can choose how the game ends and no matter what you do, you will always get the same skill points to spend on skills that you have. And you get to pick if you want to be more like a warrior that has higher stamina and can crush his foes with great swords and things that have high damage.
Or more like a mage that has devestating spells to crush any enemy
or my favorite the assasin type, letting you sneak behind characters unseen and backstabbing them and avoiding combat all together.

This really is a great game with a great story and plenty of secrets and weapons. Also it has some good graphics and plenty of enemies and characters

reviewText: Have you ever wondered how does it feel, to cast a freezing spell on an orc, then slash him into pieces with an arrow? If you did, check out Dark Messiah. The gameplay is absolutely flawless - using the environment, to destroy your enemies. If that's not enough, create your own hero: you can became a warrior, who is mastered with one handed weapons, and a shield. If you are not the fan of weapons, you can became a wizard: lethal fireballs, freezing spells, or just pick up a barrel with telekinesis, and smash their heads. Too much offensive battles? Then become a rogue! Dual-wielding daggers, and hiding in the darkness. Just stab'em in the back, or just kick them in the end of a cliff. Multiple endings (depending on which side you choose on your adventure), genial soundtrack, and the list goes on and on - absolutely marvelous game, but sadly it's way UNDERRATED! The only problem that the multiplayer isn't the best. If you like dark-fantasy, or you're an FPS-fan, but searching for something different, you should check out this masterpiece!

reviewText:
This game...it needs to win the underrated game of the universe award.  Apparently went it first released, it was hampered with bugs and over shadowed by games like Oblivion. It is a Source Engine based game that plays very much like a combination of Thief and Half Life controls/combat.  It uses chapters/missions similar to both of those games as well.  It isn't open world but that won't bother you because there is plenty of loot hidden in secret areas for you to find.  It also starts off a bit rough with a hard to understand story and uninteresting at the time, plus the combat is difficult until you get new skills/weapons.

The combat in this game is so well done, especially for a game this old.  Most people say that if Elder Scrolls had this combat, they would be the best games ever made.  You'll have so much fun kicking enemies into spikes, fire, off stairs and using the many types of weapons you find along the way.  You even get to forge a few weapons.  Once you get past the first few chapters the story and gameplay really get great. I highly suggest playing on Hard mode because it forces you to use the various methods of fighting within the environment well.  You can activate traps laced within rooms like cutting ropes on swining objects, throwing oil on the ground and lighting enemies on fire, etc.  This game was worth every penny and I can't wait to finish it.

Pros
- Brilliant Combat System (super fun)
- Variety of weapons to use and loot
- Challenging Difficulties
- Interesting Environments
- Great Inventory and Skill System
- Interactive Environments and Secrets

Cons
- Mission based
- Not Open World (plenty to explore though)
- Story is bland at times
- Steep learning curve
- Unbalanced beginning
- Slightly outdated and a few bugs remain (not the spiders)

Score 9/10

reviewText:
Best First Person Hack'n Slay ever!

Best melee combat I've experienced so far.
There's no other game that accomplished this task so well.
Your head moves depending on what attack you execute.
At any time given you have full body awareness.
All of that feels and looks very natural.
Plus you can kick enemies and objects with your boot.
How awesome is that?

Also the sound is very good.
For example, when you walk your steps sound massive
and you get a feeling for the weight of your weaponry and equipment.
I especially like the sound of walking over wood.

The medieval settings are also well done.
Overall the atmosphere is very thick.
You feel fully immersed in the dark and gritty world presented to you.

All in all it's one of my favorite games.
Melee combat wise definitely better than Dishonored
(which is another favorite game of mine)!

Only minor complaint: it's a bit too linear.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Pros
-You can set some objects, especially wooden objects, on fire.
-Rebindable keys.
-Has RPG like elements, i.e. skill tree & inventory, that gives it some replayability.
-You can pull off amazing combos: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ucSqMS4siVw
-Has different type of playstyles & routes to take to complete an objective.
-Has more than one ending.

Cons
Multiple Issues:
-Game crashes when you exit the game. An unofficial fix can be found here:         http://pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Dark_Messiah_of_Might_and_Magic#Crash_when_exiting_the_game
-Game may crash while loading a level.
-Sometimes the dialoge does not display, runs slow, or goes too fast.
-You'll be unable to read some of the tips on the loading screen if your PC loads the game too   quick.
-It is possible to get your character stuck on certain areas.
-It is possible to make your inventory & skill bar unusable after performing an assassination on enemy from a certain angle.
-The game uses a field of view of 85°, which cannot be modified even with the command default_fov #". In order to change the field of view you must enable cheats with "sv_cheats 1" then select the field of view to your liking with the command "fov #"
date:
but note that you must set your field of view again when your character gains a special ability.

Other Info:
-The game does not have large address aware enabled.
-32-bit executable.

PCGamingWiki Page: http://pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Dark_Messiah_of_Might_and_Magic
Would I buy? Yes

reviewText:
I kicked a guard in the crotch and sent him flying towards a firey death. 10/10.

Okay, seriously tho, Dark Messiah is a game that wants me to hate it: The combat is repetitive and dull early on (not to mention some of the very frustrating enemy mechanics), the story is very predictable, the environment design can sometimes be really confusing and, to top it all off, the game is riddled with glitches (but considering this is a Source based game, I think that’s to be expected).

But yet, I can’t dislike this game, no matter how hard I try: It’s incredibly immersive; it has an amazing atmosphere and succeeds at making you feel like some sort of almighty jack-of-all-trades warrior. The level design can be confusing, yes, but it’s creative and entertaining. The combat does get a lot quicker and more intense as the game goes on, and the huge “bosses” you have to fight through the game are all epic and nerve-wrecking.

Overall, this game is a recommend for me, but only to people who are willing to overlook some pretty major flaws in order to find a very entertaining and unique adventure. Fully action-based FPSRPGs are hard to find, and Dark Messiah finds that niche nicely. If nothing else, give the demo a shot. It gives you a pretty good idea of what you’re in for.

reviewText: A great blend of RPG and FPS action. Dark Messiah is many games in one with elements of the old Thief series, a wonderful cliche story line, and hours of kicking helpless orcs off of impossibly high ledges. Oh, and FIRE! reviewText: A really great and terribly underrated game. It's a bit like Half-Life mixed with Oblivion, in that it has a linear story but RPG elements that allow you to build whatever kind of character you like, whether it be a swordfighter, sorcerer, assassain, or a combination of different abilities. Has great combat and bloody fatality-style moves that are always fun to do. It even has good multiplayer, which combines classed-based point capturing like TF2 with a per-round experience system that gives you greater abilities like in the single-player (although I don't know how many people are on the multiplayer anymore). A really fun game the whole way through, and a must-play for it's price.

reviewText:
Es ist einfach der Hammer....
Und gleichzeitig eine Schande das dieses Spiel einfach so unter den anderen Genre-Vertretern untergegangen ist!
Dieses Spiel ist vom Jahre 2006 und begeistert mich vollends. Kein anderes Spiel kann weder von der Inzenierung noch von den Packenden Nahkämpfen (und/oder Fernkämpfen) heranreichen. Die Grafik ist selbst für heutige verhältnisse noch ansehlich und die möglichkeiten, einem Gegner den Garaus zu machen, sind unheimlich vielfältig!
Einfach unfassbar das dieses Spiel keine Fortsetzung bekommen hat und es so aus den Augen der Spielegemeinschaft fliegen konnte.
Über die Story mag man sich Streiten aber ich fand sie einfach nur Toll!
Man baut eine wahre beziehung zu den einzelnen Charaktern auf und wird bei einer späteren Entscheidungen auf die Probe gestellt.

Sollte jemals eine angemessene Fortsetzung kommen, und ich dafür Diablo 3 und Skyrim über Bord werfen müsste... ich würde es sofort tun!

reviewText:
This game. I rememeber playing this game years ago and not being able to finish it. It's a real hidden gem this game for people who've only recently purchased a pc (such as myself). Maybe not worth the ten pound now, but God DAMN I wanted to finish this game!

The gameplay is the real draw here and it is definitely a shame that no sequels have been made. Where Might and Magic has an incredible depth to it's history and lore, this game deals in here and now. How am I going to nutralise this guard? If I shot that cyclops in the eye would it have gone down? How badass is the magic???

All valid questions. More dedicated players will have more to come back for in the sense of difficulty. However, I'm not that guy! I found it a good challenge to play with mouse and keyboard on just normal, but then again I am a recent adopter!

Most definitely my favourite purchase on steam so far. All the hours are worth experiencing even if the story is a little droll compared to the action.

reviewText:
Probably one of my most replayed singleplayer games because of all the different ways you bring pain to the not so defenseless (and quite tough!) enemies. Wether it be outplaying them in the way of melee combat or simply being a lil bich and chucking a barrel right in their face, this game offers many, MANY ways to play it with its huge replay value.


Wanna be a spell-casting mage that still fights with swords with the occasional use of bows?
Go right the hell ahead, there is absolutely no limitations that stop you from doing just that.
The incredible versatility and depth of the combat system provides many etertaining ways to dispatch enemies.

Learn ice magic and freeze your enemies. Discover that you can use said spell on the ground and create a patch of ice, watch and laugh your ♥♥♥ off as 5 orcs coming to chase you all slip on said ice and fall to their deaths. This is just one of the many past times you'll come to see in this game

The game is built on the source engine and makes use of all the nice, juicy physics engine that we've all come to love over time. Pick up heavy objects and toss it at enemies which results in the enemy stumbling hilariously in whatever direction the object was thrown in. Use your mighty Duke Nukem boot to send a baddy flying down a crevice or to send them into the many VERY  convinently traps.

The RPG elements certainly blend well with the game, with the skill trees being flexible and many of the skills being quite handy. You are also able to spread your skills however you please so it opens up many possibilities on different playstyles that will certainly not all be experienced in just one single playthrough.

reviewText:
Disclaimer: This game is extremely buggy on Windows 7. Alt-tabbing is almost guaranteed to crash it. Sometimes it just crashes because it feels like it.

Other than that, this game is great. The world is fairly generic high fantasy, but it does have a dark atmosphere to it that sets it apart. The game is called Might and Magic" - but by far the most fun and viable way to play the game is Might. The first person melee combat is actually enjoyable and fairly deep.

The most fun part of the game
